FGT5018.001.Name: Vandalism of Network Infrastructure: Cabling and junction boxes
FGT5018.001.Description: An adversary targets unprotected cables and junction boxes in order to disrupt service.

Detection.description:
Security Incident and event monitoring
Event logs recording user activities, exceptions, faults and information security events should be produced, kept and regularly reviewed. Additional considerations: development of use-case specific alert rules, integration and correlation of data at all levels (network, application), integration and correlation with service provider-level monitoring mechanisms.

Pre-Conditions.name: Unprotected cables
Pre-Conditions.description: Fibers routed between pieces of equipment without proper protection are susceptible to damage, which can critically affect network reliability. The fiber cable management system should therefore ensure that every fiber is protected from physical damage.

Pre-Conditions.name: Unprotected junction boxes
Pre-Conditions.description: Lack of protection of junction boxes / splice closures. Improper cable routing also causes increased congestion in the termination panel and the cableways, increasing the possibility of bend radius violations and long-term failure.

Post-Conditions.name: Service unavailability
Post-Conditions.description: Destruction or damage of these assets may cause an unavailability of resources.

Post-Conditions.name: Information destruction
Post-Conditions.description: Destruction or damage of these assets may cause information destruction

Procedure Examples.name: Disrupt service via physical damage
Procedure Examples.description: An adversary may damage cabling and junction boxes

Critical Assets.name: Data cables
Critical Assets.description: Data cables used in the operator network infrastructure

Critical Assets.name: Power cables
Critical Assets.description: Power cables used in the operator network infrastructure

References.name: European Union Agency for Cybersecurity (ENISA): “ENISA Threat Landscape for 5G Networks” Report, page 210, December 2020.
ISO/IEC 27011:(2016), “Information technology — Security techniques — Code of practice for Information security controls based on ISO/IEC 27002 for telecommunications organizations”

Mitigations.name: FGM5005
Mitigations.description:
Compliance with cable standards.
Raceway / conduit is one of the easiest ways to protect any cable, fiber optic included. These hollow pieces of plastic act like a protective outer shell.

Mitigations.name: FGM5005
Mitigations.description:
Implement physical and environmental controls.
Sites should be provided with a full set of physical and environmental controls aimed to assure access control, monitoring, continuity of operations and protection against environmental disasters

Mitigations.name: FGM5540
Mitigations.description: Power supply facilities in the isolated area such as mobile base stations should preferably provide an uninterruptible power supply with capacity for all loading and capable of withstanding primary power supply failures for the duration of likely outages. If that is impossible, a mechanism to provide uninterruptible power to critical equipment should be installed. Batteries may need to be augmented with a private electric generator, especially in isolated areas.

FGT1195.501.Name: SIM Credential Theft
FGT1195.501.Description: An adversary may get access to several SIM credentials either by physical access to SIM card inventory or by compromising  SIM repository.

Procedure Examples.name: Infiltrate SIM vendor’s network.
Procedure Examples.description: Allegedly: the UK agency GHCQ planted malware on Gemalto servers to obtain SIM credentials. The number of keys obtained were in the order of millions. [1]

Critical Assets.name: Privacy of subscriber data and voice traffic
Critical Assets.description: Adversary is after getting the keys to decrypt cellular communications for those sets of SIMs whose credentials it captured.

References.name: Daily Mail.com, news article 20 Feb 2015, "US and UK spies hacked SIM card manufacturer to steal codes that allowed them to eavesdrop on mobile phones worldwide, according to bombshell documents leaked by Ed Snowden".
GSMA FS.28 “Security Guidelines for Exchange of UICC Credentials”, Version 1.0, November 2020.

Mitigations.name: M1017
Mitigations.description: Personnel security: Train personnel in SIM card OEMs to be wary of social engineering and other attempts of unauthorized parties to gain access to any relevant resource, and to report suspicious activities

Mitigations.name: M1030
Mitigations.description: Physical and cyber security of IT systems, servers.

Mitigations.name: M1022
Mitigations.description: Restrict access to files exchanged between SIM vendor and MNO

Mitigations.name: M1041
Mitigations.description: Protect the files where SIM data is stored by encryption

Mitigations.name: FGM1557
Mitigations.description: Protect the files where SIM data is stored by integrity protection

FGT1557.503.Name: Non-SBI
FGT1557.503.Description: An adversary with access to Non-Service Based Interfaces (Non-SBI) network nodes (including routers/switches/load balancers) may position themselves in order to  support follow-on behaviors such as  [Network Sniffing](/techniques/FGT1040) or [Transmitted Data Manipulation](/techniques/FGT1565.002).

Detection.description: Inspect Network traffic content and watch for unauthorized changes as the packets move through the routers/middle boxes
Check configuration changes in all switches/routers. Configuration audits by OSS/BSS

Pre-Conditions.name: Compromised or misconfigured switches/routers
Pre-Conditions.description: Malware or wrong configuration in switches/routers between RAN and core and between gNBs

Post-Conditions.name: Both CP and UP data are eavesdropped or modified by AiTM attack
Post-Conditions.description: Both UE signaling and normal data communication with network will be impacted.

Procedure Examples.name: Compromised or misconfigured switches or routers between RAN and core and between gNBs
Procedure Examples.description: Integrity or confidentiality protection can be disabled on N2 interface for CP, N3 interface for UP and Xn interface for CP and UP. Clauses 9.2, 9.3 and 9.4 of [2]

Procedure Examples.name: Adversary configures the non-SBI interfaces to not use IPSec.
Procedure Examples.description: gNB does not provide protection on N2, N3, Xn interfaces, see clause D.2.2. of [1]

Critical Assets.description: UE signaling integrity and confidentiality

FGT5019.006.Name: Subscriber Profile Identifier Discovery: Silent SMS
FGT5019.006.Description: Adversary sends a spoofed or silent SMS to trigger paging of UE, to retrieve the subscriber profile identifier.

FGT5031.Description: An adversary may discover a valid GTP-U TEID in order to apply additional techniques.

FGT5046.Name: Program Wrapper
FGT5046.Description: Adversaries may create or modify system-level processes to retain access, prevent detection, and open communication paths with C2 servers and new targets

Detection.description: Monitor application logs for unusual requests or rate of requests
Monitor for unusual volumes or sources of requests to the service

Pre-Conditions.description: Adversary may need to identify vulnerabilities in the API to obtain initial-access, unauthorized information, or perform a denial of service

Pre-Conditions.name: API credentials
Pre-Conditions.description: Adversary may need to obtain credentials to collect unauthorized information

Mitigations.name: M1016
Mitigations.description: Vulnerability scanning of public APIs

Mitigations.name: M1050
Mitigations.description: Use WAF to minimize potential exploit of vulnerabilities

Mitigations.name: M1037
Mitigations.description: Use of network based DDoS mitigation capabilities to filter traffic upstream

Detection.description: Often these third-party applications will have logs of their own that can be collected and correlated with other data from the environment. Ensure that third-party application logs are on-boarded to the enterprise logging system and the logs are regularly reviewed. Audit software deployment logs and look for suspicious or unauthorized activity. A system not typically used to push software to clients that suddenly is used for such a task outside of a known admin function may be suspicious. Monitor account login activity on these applications to detect suspicious/abnormal usage. Perform application deployment at regular times so that irregular deployment activity stands out.

Monitor for newly executed processes that does not correlate to known good software. Analyze the process execution trees, historical activities from the third-party application (such as what types of files are usually pushed), and the resulting activities or events from the file/binary/script pushed to systems.

Procedure Examples.description: has used RAdmin, a remote software tool used to remotely control workstations and ATMs
It is believed that a patch management system for an anti-virus product commonly installed among targeted companies was used to distribute the  malware

Mitigations.name: M1018
Mitigations.description: User Account Management, limited and least privileged user accounts

Mitigations.name: M1051
Mitigations.description: Update Software regularly to eliminate persistence

Mitigations.name: M1029
Mitigations.description: Remote Data Storage, restrict access and monitor repository activity
Privileged Account Management, unique, least privileged accounts and regularly audit access attempts audits

FGT5035.Name: Radio Reception Degradation
FGT5035.Description: An adversary transmits radio signals to degrade reception and demodulation of signals to the UE or gNB/eNB.

FGT5003.Name: Network Function Service Discovery
FGT5003.Description: An adversary may query the Network Repository Function (NRF) to discover restricted   Network Function (NF) services to further target that NF.

Detection.description: Logging of all access requests/inquiries

Pre-Conditions.name: Access to NRF
Pre-Conditions.description: NRF is by design open to connections from other network functions. Control of another NF in the operator domain may be required.

Pre-Conditions.name: Access to SCP
Pre-Conditions.description: SCP is compromised to hijack tokens.

Post-Conditions.name: Unauthorized probing of network services
Post-Conditions.description: Information of what other services are provided by a given MNO

Procedure Examples.name: Access token abuse
Procedure Examples.description: A malicious NF can abuse access token issued by the NRF for one slice to access another shared NF in a different slice. Clause H.2.2.1 of [2]

Procedure Examples.name: Access token hijack
Procedure Examples.description: Access tokens can be hijacked by a compromised intermediate proxy such as SCP (if deployed by operator). This attack can be followed by re-direct or replay of access tokens. Clause 3.9 of [3]

Critical Assets.name: Operator network components and services
Critical Assets.description: It is possible for example to find out whether an operator provides services to a certain customer. Or whether a user is also part of a private slice e.g. DOD. There is slice isolation assurance loss with this threat.

References.name: R. Pell, S. Moschoyiannis, E. Panaousis, R. Heartfield, “Towards dynamic threat modelling in 5G core networks based on MITRE ATT&CK”, October 2021
3GPP Technical Report 33.926, “Security Assurance Specification (SCAS) threats and critical assets in 3GPP network product classes”, Release 17.
Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF) “OAuth 2.0 Security Best Current Practice”, draft-ietf-oauth-security-topics-05, June 2022.

Mitigations.name: FGM5003
Mitigations.description:
Ensure cross-layer checks at the NRF, between the certificate presented to it at the TLS connection setup stage and the identity and authorization requested presented to it at the OAuth Token request stage.
Ensure the consumer is authorized to ask about this service.

Authorization follows need-to-know rules, such as:
1. a NF can not query for NFs in other network slices
2. a NF can only query for NFs that it needs to communicate with.

Mitigations.name: FGM5501
Mitigations.description: Inspect proxy servers such as SCP (if deployed) for any suspicious use of access tokens such as unauthorized re-direct or replay of tokens

FGT5039.Name: Manipulate Virtual Network Function (VNF) Configuration
FGT5039.Description: Adversaries may bridge network boundaries by modifying a network device's Virtual Network Function Configuration.

Detection.description: Use verification of distributed binaries through hash checking or other integrity checking mechanisms. Scan downloads for malicious signatures and attempt to test software and updates prior to deployment while taking note of potential suspicious activity.

Perform physical inspection of hardware to look for potential tampering. Perform integrity checking on pre-OS boot mechanisms that can be manipulated for malicious purposes and compare against known good baseline behavior.

References.name: ETSI NFV SEC001, “Network Functions Virtualization (NFV); NFV Security; Problem Statement”, Jan. 2014, section 6.9

Mitigations.name: M1051
Mitigations.description: Update Software regularly

Mitigations.name: M1016
Mitigations.description: Vulnerability Scanning of software before it is brought into MNO environment as well as regular scans to detect abnormal behavior

FGT5020.Name: Retrieve UE subscription data
FGT5020.Description: An adversary controlling a control plane network function (NF) may manipulate signaling to retrieve UE subscription information.

Detection.description: Monitor logs

Pre-Conditions.name: SUPI or GPSI
Pre-Conditions.description: Adversary must know the value of the SUPI or GPSI identifiers for the UE

Procedure Examples.name: AMF retrieves subscription data from UDM.
Procedure Examples.description: An AMF can extract subscription data (including NSSAIs) for any given UE SUPI by asking the UDM (uses Nudm_SDM_Get service  (SDM=SubscriberDataManagement)). The UDM does not check that that AMF is the one serving the UE, i.e. the AMF does not need to register itself first as serving the UE, via the Nudm_UECM_Registration Request. Table 5.2.3.1-1 of [1]

Procedure Examples.name: AMF in visited PLMN retrieves UE information during 5GS to EPC roaming.
Procedure Examples.description: A rogue AMF in visited PLMN can retrieve the UE’s sensitive information during 5GS to EPC roaming.. AMF calls Nsmf_PDUSession_ContextRequest API to v/hSMF. SMF sends the UE SM context in response which can reveal the following UE information: SUPI, S-NSSAI, DNN, UE IP address etc. Section 4.11.1.2.1 & Table 5.2.8.2.10-1 of [1]

Procedure Examples.name: SMF retrieves subscription data from UDM
Procedure Examples.description: The SMF can send to UDM a Nudm-sdm message and retrieve “Session mgmt subscription data”, i.e. DNN configuration for all network slices.

Procedure Examples.name: UDM can look up any UE (in UDR if one is employed).
Procedure Examples.description: The UDM can legitimately get UE subscription data from UDR.

Procedure Examples.name: SMSF retrieves UE subscription data from UDM
Procedure Examples.description: The SMSF can get the UE subscription data via Nudm_sdm API.

Procedure Examples.name: NEF retrieves some of the UE subscription data from UDM.
Procedure Examples.description: The NEF can get the UE subscription data via Nudm_sdm API.

Critical Assets.name: UDM and subscriber/UE data
Critical Assets.description: Subscriber data can be permanent (not updateable) or updateable (like the current serving PLMN, AMF etc)

References.name: 3rd Generation Partnership Project (3GPP) 23.502 “Procedures for the 5G System (5GS)”, March 2022.

Mitigations.name: FGM5033
Mitigations.description:
Standard 5G enterprise/core network security functionality
E.g. Zero trust principles for OA&M.

FGT5009.002.Name: Weaken Integrity: Network Interfaces
FGT5009.002.Description: An adversary may change the configuration of network nodes so as to disable or weaken integrity protection on the network interfaces Non-SBI, SBI and Roaming, thus allowing for transmitted data manipulation.

Detection.description: Inspect network traffic and watch for unauthorized changes as the packets move through the interfaces.

Check configuration changes in gNB, NFs, SEPP and MME.
Run configuration audits by OSS/BSS.

Pre-Conditions.name: Rogue or misconfigured AMF or SMF or gNB or UPF or SEPP or MME or any other core NF
Pre-Conditions.description: Adversary must have access to the network components to cause the attacks

Post-Conditions.name: UE at risk of data manipulation
Post-Conditions.description: UE signaling with network and user plane data may be impacted. This can be used to cause DoS attack.

Post-Conditions.name: Network signaling at risk of data manipulation
Post-Conditions.description: Network communication within core network or on the non-SBI interfaces or on roaming interface may be impacted.

Procedure Examples.name: Compromised or misconfigured gNB
Procedure Examples.description: A rogue or misconfigured gNB can disable IPSec integrity or use a weak IPSec integrity algorithm on backhaul interfaces such as N2, N3 and Xn. Then it can launch other attacks. Clause D.2.2 of [1], clause 5.3.3 of [2].

Procedure Examples.name: Compromised or misconfigured AMF
Procedure Examples.description: A rogue or misconfigured AMF can disable IPSec integrity or use a weak IPSec integrity algorithm on N2 and N26 interfaces. Then it can launch other attacks. Clause K.2.1 of [1], clause 5.5.2  of [2]

Procedure Examples.name: Compromised or misconfigured UPF
Procedure Examples.description: A rogue or misconfigured UPF can disable IPSec integrity or use a weak IPSec integrity algorithm on N3, N4 and N9 interfaces. Then it can launch other attacks. Clause L.2.1 of [1]

Procedure Examples.name: Compromised or misconfigured SMF
Procedure Examples.description: A rogue or misconfigured SMF can disable IPSec integrity or use a weak IPSec integrity algorithm on N4 interface. Then it can launch other attacks. Clause 9.9 of [2]

Procedure Examples.name: Compromised or misconfigured NF
Procedure Examples.description:
A rogue or misconfigured NF can disable the TLS integrity or use a weak TLS integrity algorithm to another NF including the SCP (if deployed). Then it can launch other attacks to gain unauthorized access to network services. Clause 13.1 of [2]

If SCP is rogue or misconfigured, it can force TLS connections to all NFs to be unencrypted or use weak integrity for all. Clause 5.9.2.4 of [2]

Procedure Examples.name: Compromised or misconfigured SEPP or IPX component
Procedure Examples.description:
A rogue or misconfigured SEPP can disable TLS integrity or use a weak TLS integrity algorithm on N32-c interface or N32-f interface or both.

A rogue or misconfigured IPX component can disable JWS integrity or use a weak integrity algorithm when PRINS is used on N32-f. Then it can launch other attacks. Clauses 13.1 and 13.2 of [2]

Procedure Examples.name: Compromised or misconfigured MME/AMF, or UPF.
Procedure Examples.description:
A rogue or misconfigured AMF/MME can disable IPSec integrity or use a weak IPSec integrity algorithm on N26 interface. Then it can launch other attacks. Clause K.2.1 of [1], 8.4 of [2].

A rogue or misconfigured UPF can disable IPSec integrity or use a weak IPSec integrity algorithm on the N9 interface between home PLMN UPF and visited PLMN UPF. See clause 9.9, 13.1 and 13.2 of [2]

FGT5012.001.Name: Locate UE: Passive radio signals observation
FGT5012.001.Description: An adversary may non-cooperatively geolocate a UE from UE radio signals externals.

Pre-Conditions.description: Attacker must have radio line-of-sight to target for most accurate geolocation.

Post-Conditions.name: Subsequent attack
Post-Conditions.description: Geolocation can make electronic attack for degradation of service more effective, bidding down to defeat ID and traffic confidentiality more effective, and can expose subscriber to physical attack.

Procedure Examples.description: Adversary geolocates unknown UE using some combination of Direction of Arrival, Time-of-Arrival, and/or Frequency-of-Arrival of UE signal externals.

FGT5007.Description: An adversary, such as an insider to the MNO or vendor, could install a malicious NF into the core network, in order to launch other attacks or get access to information.

Procedure Examples.description: Rogue NF calls Nnrf_NFManagement API to register one of these functions: AMF, SMF, UDM, AUSF, NEF, PCF, SMSF, NSSF, UPF, etc. Clause 5.2.7 of [3]

Critical Assets.description: Network services provided to UEs.

Mitigations.name: FGM5091
Mitigations.description: Mutual authentication between SDN controller and network elements, SDN controller and SDN application can prevent unauthorized access

Mitigations.name: FGM1557
Mitigations.description: Strong integrity protection method should be employed on APIs carrying control plane traffic between Controller and network element as well as controller and SDN application to avoid adversary in the middle threats

Mitigations.name: M1041
Mitigations.description: Strong encryption should be used on APIs carrying control plane traffic between Controller and network element as well as controller and SDN application to avoid adversary in the middle threats

Mitigations.name: FGM5090
Mitigations.description: Logs from SDN Controller and network elements must be corelated to ensure unauthorize activity is reported. Similarly flow rules change log should be reviewed and reconciled with authorized changes.

Mitigations.name: M1053
Mitigations.description: SDN controller configurations should be backed up and periodically audited to see differences between running configuration and back up configurations

Mitigations.name: M1054
Mitigations.description: Keep baseline configuration up to date to avoid loopholes due to stale configuration or configuration drift.

Mitigations.name: M1030
Mitigations.description: Physical and logical segmentation can prevent lateral movements. Segmentation techniques in the hosts and network will reduce the chances of lateral movement to the control.

FGT5013.Name: Malicious VNF Instantiation
FGT5013.Description: An adversary may use a fake or compromised container management controller to deploy fake VNFs to collect information from the network.

Detection.description: Audit application logs (NFVO, VIM).  Configuration management databases (CMDB) and other asset management systems may help with the detection of computer systems or network devices that should not exist on a network.
Monitor container creation, container start events
Monitor POD creation and modification events.

Procedure Examples.name: S0683
Procedure Examples.description: Peirates can deploy a pod that mounts its node’s root file system, then execute a command to create a reverse shell on the node

Procedure Examples.name: S0600
Procedure Examples.description: Doki was run through a deployed container

Procedure Examples.name: G0139
Procedure Examples.description: TeamTNT has deployed different types of containers into victim environments to facilitate execution.

Critical Assets.name: Container and Container engines
Critical Assets.description: Container and container engine may expose privileged information to adversary directly from process  or thru container engine.

Critical Assets.name: Container Management Controller system
Critical Assets.description: In Container management architecture (Kubernetes for example) adversary may use Kublet commands or API proxy to gain access to information and control of the container.

Critical Assets.name: NFO
Critical Assets.description: NF orchestrators

References.name:
ETSI NFV SEC025, Secure End-to-End VNF and NS management specification
Release 4, section 4.4.3, accessed 6/28/2022

Mitigations.name: M1047
Mitigations.description: Scan images before deployment, and block those that are not in compliance with security policies. In Kubernetes environments, the admission controller can be used to validate images after a container deployment request is authenticated but before the container is deployed.

Mitigations.name: M1035
Mitigations.description: Limit communications with the container service to local Unix sockets or remote access via SSH. Require secure port access to communicate with the APIs over TLS by disabling unauthenticated access to the Docker API, Kubernetes API Server, and container orchestration web applications.

Mitigations.name: M1030
Mitigations.description: Deny direct remote access to internal systems through the use of network proxies, gateways, and firewalls.

Mitigations.name: M1018
Mitigations.description: Enforce the principle of least privilege by limiting container dashboard access to only the necessary users.

FGT5012.004.Name: Locate UE: Core Network Function Signaling
FGT5012.004.Description: An adversary in the core network exploits signaling protocols to obtain the location of the UE.

Pre-Conditions.name: Access to SS7 network
Pre-Conditions.description: Adversary may pretend to be an operator supporting only older generations

Pre-Conditions.name: Access to operator’s network function
Pre-Conditions.description: Adversary has to gain control of one core NF, or UPF or NEF.

Pre-Conditions.name: Knowledge of the UE SUPI or 5G-GUTI of target UE
Pre-Conditions.description: UE identifier required for all Core network function abuse

Procedure Examples.name: Adversary uses SS7 interconnect (IWF) to a 5G network without protection (firewalls, etc). to obtain UE location information
Procedure Examples.description: From [3], there were recent successful attacks on SS7 whereby an attacker with access to the SS7 interconnection can find a user’s location, as well as billing data and Short Message Service (SMS) messages. In addition, the attacker can also eavesdrop on user data.

Procedure Examples.name: Adversary gains control of a core NF to get location info for a given UE: AMF case
Procedure Examples.description: The AMF gets UE location legitimately from LMF (Nlmf-loc API). [Section 8.3 of TS 23.273]. In addition, an adversary can modify AMF behavior so that it doesn't allocate a new 5G-GUTI to a given UE, so that that UE can be tracked via listening devices in the area, see [FGT5012.003](/techniques/FGT5012.003)

Procedure Examples.name: Adversary gains control of a core NF to get location info for a given UE: AF case
Procedure Examples.description: Incorrect implementation/configuration in NEF can allow a rogue application function (AF) to access UE location information using LMF services. [Section 6.1.2 of TS23.273]

Procedure Examples.name: Adversary gains control of a core NF to get location info for a given UE: SMF case
Procedure Examples.description: The SMF can obtain a UE's location whenever the AMF sends it a PDU update request:  Nsmf_PDUSession_UpdateSMContextRequest (which contains UE location info, which can be: E-UTRA or NR cell id, location timestamp, “geographicalInformation” in hex format as in TS 23.032, only ellipsoid point with uncertainty circle.) [section 5.2.8.2.6 of TS23.502]

Procedure Examples.name: Adversary gains control of a core NF to get location info for a given UE: UDM case
Procedure Examples.description: The UDM can legitimately ask the AMF for the location of a UE using Namf_Location service. [5.2.2.1 of TS23.502]

Procedure Examples.name: Adversary gains control of a core NF to get location info for a given UE: UPF case
Procedure Examples.description: The UPF has access to serving cell ID for UEs that are actively sending data (RRC connected).

Procedure Examples.name: Adversary gains control of a core NF to get location info for a given UE: NEF case
Procedure Examples.description: The NEF can legitimately ask AMF Namf_EventExposure or ask GMLC directly - then GMLC gives the NEF a location report (Note: NEFs serve as location proxies to internal and external AFs in the same way GMLCs serve as proxies to external LCS clients). [5.2.2.1 of TS23.502]

Procedure Examples.name: Adversary gains control of a core NF to get location info for a given UE: NWDAF case
Procedure Examples.description: The  NWDAF can get coarse UE location by subscribing to events from AMF. [5.2.2.1 of TS23.502]

Procedure Examples.name: Adversary gains control of a core NF to get location info for a given UE: GMLC case
Procedure Examples.description: The GMLC can legitimately ask the AMF for the location of a given UE using Namf_Location service. [5.2.2.1 of TS23.502]

Procedure Examples.name: Adversary gains control of a core NF to get location info for a given UE: LMF case
Procedure Examples.description: The LMF can initiate location procedure with the UE. [6.11.1, 6.11.2, 6.11.3 of TS23.273]

Critical Assets.name: Operator network components
Critical Assets.description: NEF, AMF, SMF, UPF, NWDAF, GMLC, LMF

Critical Assets.name: UE location
Critical Assets.description: UE/User geographical location

References.name: S.P. Rao, S. Holtmanns, T. Aura: “Threat modeling framework for mobile communication systems”, May 2020
R. Pell, S. Moschoyiannis, E. Panaousis, R. Heartfield, “Towards dynamic threat modelling in 5G core networks based on MITRE ATT&CK”,  October 2021
S. Holtmanns, S. P. Rao, I. Oliver, “User location tracking attacks for LTE networks using the interworking functionality”, 2016 IFIP Networking Conference.

Mitigations.name: M1037
Mitigations.description: Filter out request messages that come from external (to the operator) sources to guard against SS7 attacks

Mitigations.name: FGM5019
Mitigations.description: NEF authorizes 3rd party AFs for location service using policy. Nnef_Location API called by AF should be authorized properly. AF uses GPSI as UE identity.

Mitigations.name: FGM1506
Mitigations.description: Periodic authentication / authorization of NF consumer e.g. AMF by NRF will help detect rogue AMFs. Not currently in 3GPP specs, but it can be enhanced.

FGT5018.004.Name: Vandalism of Network Infrastructure: Theft of Assets
FGT5018.004.Description: An adversary accesses a shared site, or remote location, with intent to steal valuable materials (such as copper, batteries, and fuel) for resale.

Detection.description: Event logs recording user activities, exceptions, faults and information security events should be produced, kept and regularly reviewed. Additional considerations: development of use-case specific alert rules, integration and correlation of data at all levels (network, application), integration and correlation with service provider-level monitoring mechanisms.

Pre-Conditions.name: Improper security monitoring of remote/shared facilities
Pre-Conditions.description: Remote/shared sites have to be integrated in the network-wide Security Incident and Monitoring System, but with additional considerations: development of use-case specific alert rules, integration and correlation of data at all levels (network, application), integration and correlation with service provider -level monitoring mechanisms. Failure to do so may leave advanced or sustained threats undetected, as well as technical failures or malfunctions of local resources.

Post-Conditions.name: Service unavailability
Post-Conditions.description: Theft of these assets may cause an unavailability of resources.

Post-Conditions.name: Increased maintenance costs
Post-Conditions.description: Theft of these assets may cause an increase in maintenance costs for the operator.

Procedure Examples.name: Cable/Copper Theft
Procedure Examples.description: Copper’s value transforms remote cellular base stations into prime targets for thieves. The costs for telecom and tower operators to replace the cost of the cable and damage to the site can be thousands of dollars per incident. This is not taking into consideration the additional costs of loss of network service. Even the theft of a small amount of copper can cause extensive damage to site equipment, costing cell towers owners thousands of dollars in repairs, replacement, and network downtime. There are several expensive copper items at cell sites that are very attractive to thieves, such as the ground wires, copper grounding busbars, and waveguides

Procedure Examples.name: Battery Theft
Procedure Examples.description: Battery theft can easily become the root cause of cell services outage. Similarly, to the case of cable theft, telecom towers are increasingly affected by the rise of battery theft and vandalism incidents.

Procedure Examples.name: Fuel Theft
Procedure Examples.description: Fuel is a major asset at telecom sites that can easily and directly be sold by thieves. The threat of diesel theft is widespread in many emerging markets and even in the rural areas of the developed markets.

Critical Assets.name: Physical assets and commodities
Critical Assets.description: Physical assets and commodities used by the mobile network operators in their infrastructure.

References.name: European Union Agency for Cybersecurity (ENISA): “ENISA Threat Landscape for 5G Networks” Report, page 202, December 2020.
Baars, J. “White Paper - Telecom Sites Physical Security”, December 2019, Asentria

Mitigations.name: FGM5005
Mitigations.description:
Implement physical and environmental controls
Shared/Remote sites should be provided with a full set of physical and environmental controls aimed to assure access control, monitoring, continuity of operations and protection against environmental disasters. Failure to do so may lead to unauthorized access, destruction of assets and impairment of operations.

FGT5010.Name: Fraudulent AMF registration for UE in UDM
FGT5010.Description: An adversary-controlled AMF registers itself in the UDM as the serving network for a victim’s UE, enabling further attacks like fraud or the retrieval of the UE’s subscription data.

Pre-Conditions.name: Faulty UDM implementation
Pre-Conditions.description: If the UDM does not store the authentication status of a UE, or the authentication status is incorrect

Post-Conditions.name: A rogue AMF could perform other hostile action on the victim UE
Post-Conditions.description: A rogue AMF could mount other attacks on the victim UE, but the UE is not currently registered on the network

Procedure Examples.name: Adversary registers an AMF it controls as the one serving a given UE that just de-registered
Procedure Examples.description:
An adversary in control of an AMF registers that AMF in UDM (via Nudm_UECM_Registration Request) as serving a given UE that de-registered. If the UDM implementation does not update the authentication status of UEs as de-registered, it will accept that AMF. The adversary-controlled AMF can then potentially perform additional hostile actions such as fraud, claiming to have provided services (for roaming UEs), or obtaining other UE information from the UDM.
Note that the UDM does not communicate with the AMF based on OAuth tokens. Since AMF to UDM signaling is part of the key UE control plane, it may be that they have a permanent TLS connection (TBC)

Critical Assets.name: UDM functionality
Critical Assets.description: Functionality of this core network function

Critical Assets.name: UE data
Critical Assets.description: Data (user or control) belonging to the UE

Critical Assets.name: UE location
Critical Assets.description: Physical geo-location (course or fine) of the UE

References.name: 3rd Generation Partnership Project (3GPP)  TR 33.926: “Security Assurance Specification (SCAS) threats and critical assets in 3GPP network product classes”, Technical Report, v17.3.0, Dec. 2021, clause E.2.2.3
3rd Generation Partnership Project (3GPP)  TR 33.846,” Study on authentication enhancements in the 5G System (5GS)”, Technical Report, v17.0.0, December 2021, clause 5.3.1.2
European Union Agency for Cybersecurity (ENISA): “ENISA Threat Landscape for 5G Networks” Report, December 2020
3GPP contribution (2019)

Mitigations.name: FGM5013
Mitigations.description: Implement security as per clause 6.1.9 of 3GPP TS 29.503, namely OAuth2.0

Mitigations.name: FGM5014
Mitigations.description: Cross check whether the requesting AMF is likely to be the one serving that UE now. Validate the expected geography of where UE actually may be, in comparison to the area that the requester AMF is supposed to serve.

Mitigations.name: FGM1506
Mitigations.description:
Periodic authentication / authorization of NF consumer e.g. AMF by NRF will help detect rogue AMFs. 
Not currently in 3GPP/GSMA (TBC) specs, but it can be enhanced. It’s process management (OA&M)

FGT5019.003.Name: Subscriber Profile Identifier Discovery: Obtain subscriber identifier via NF
FGT5019.003.Description: An adversary in control of an Application Function (AF) or a rogue Network Function (NF) can make an API call to obtain the Subscriber Permanent Identifier (SUPI) or other sensitive UE information.

Detection.description: Logging of AF inquiries for UEs that they don’t serve. Post process the logs to detect fraudulent API calls by rogue AF or NF.

Pre-Conditions.name: UE phone number and control of AF/NF
Pre-Conditions.description: Adversary has knowledge of UE phone number/GPSI and has control over an AF or NEF or AMF.

Post-Conditions.name: SUPI is available to the adversary
Post-Conditions.description: If SUPI is obtained, many other subsequent attacks are possible such as subscriber identity spoofing and location tracking.

Procedure Examples.name: Retrieve UE SUPI via API
Procedure Examples.description:
The NEF stores the UE data – including SUPI-- in UDR and responds to API requests from various AFs. An adversary in control of an (external) AF uses legitimate SBA API to retrieve subscriber identifier of victim UE (SUPI) from their phone number. 

The API that the AF calls is Nnef_ApplyPolicy_Create API, it is sent to NEF with UE's GPSI/phone number. NEF retrieves the SUPI from UDM by using Nudm_SDM_Get API. See Section 4.15.6.8 of [1].

Alternatively, Rogue NEF retrieves SUPI from GPSI/phone number using Nudm_SDM_Get API towards the UDM, See section 4.13.2.2 of [1].

Procedure Examples.name: Retrieve UE’s sensitive information via rogue NF
Procedure Examples.description:
The AMF can obtain some sensitive information about a UE it serves (or claims to serve). A rogue AMF in visited PLMN retrieves UE’s sensitive information from the home PLMN by calling an API when UE roams from 5GS to EPC.

AMF asks the SMF for UE Session Management context, and thus can obtain the following sensitive information: Permanent identifier (SUPI), the names of the slices the UE is subscribed to (S-NSSAIs), the name of the data network the UE is connected to, and the IP address of the UE. (The AMF API call to SMF is Nsmf_PDUSession_ContextRequest API, see Section 4.11.1.2.1 & Table 5.2.8.2.10-1 of [1])

Critical Assets.name: UE permanent identity (SUPI)
Critical Assets.description: If SUPI is stolen, many other subsequent attacks are possible such as subscriber identity spoofing and location tracking.

References.name: 3rd Generation Partnership Project (3GPP) TS 23.502, “Procedures for the 5G System (5GS); Stage 2 (Release 17)”, v17.4.0, March 2022.

Mitigations.name: FGM5019
Mitigations.description: NEF should check that UE in question is subscribed to services of the AF. This way, unauthorized access by external rogue AFs can be avoided.

FGT1592.501.Name: Internal resource search
FGT1592.501.Description: An adversary may gain access to an operator's roaming database (IR.21), which can reveal the critical network assets of both the operator and its roaming partners.

Detection.description: Access to IR.21 file should be logged.
Leaking this information in the Internet is obvious

Pre-Conditions.name: Access to GSMA account; in some cases, none.
Pre-Conditions.description: Adversary needs to access the operator databases or GSMA repositories

Post-Conditions.name: Discovered IP addresses
Post-Conditions.description: IP addresses of core network functions known

Procedure Examples.name: IR.21 accessible from the Internet
Procedure Examples.description: Claro Americas, and Vivo telecom, had their IR.21 database accessible from an internet in 2016 (References [2], [3] no longer accessible).

Critical Assets.name: Mobile network topology, interconnects.
Critical Assets.description: Information on the IP addresses of the mobile network, along with those of the interconnect/roaming nodes.

Critical Assets.name: IP addresses of core NFs
Critical Assets.description: Hostnames and IP addresses of core network functions like subscriber databases and functions involved in roaming exchanges (e.g. Access and Mobility Function (AMF)).

References.name: S.P. Rao, S. Holtmanns, T. Aura: “Threat modeling framework for mobile communication systems”, May 2020
Claro Americas IR.21 Data, Accessed 30-June-2016
Vivo Brazil IR.21 Data, Accessed 30-June-2016.

Mitigations.name: FGM5500
Mitigations.description: Control access to IR.21 files in GSMA. Host/application hosting this file should guard against such leak.

Detection.description: File changes of any sort that cannot be traced back to authorized change.
Software image inconsistency.  Signature and checksum mismatch
Kernel executing unknow processes or unauthorized processes not typical of the host.
Network traffic pattern may reveal remote C2 communication from rootkit
Active processes or process log may reveal unauthorized activity due to rootkits
Background services not typically associated with the host
System may have reboots, or unexpected performance degradation, may be slow to respond to inputs.

Critical Assets.name: Physical, Virtual, and cloud native functions
Critical Assets.description: NFVI components that support virtualization and network connecting the virtual functions.

Critical Assets.name: Hosts
Critical Assets.description: Any compute entity that supports data processing functions, including Linux/Windows hosts, VMs, and or specialty equipment that has address and interacts with other NFVI elements.

References.name: ETSI NFV SEC025, Secure E2E VNF & NS management spec (WIP) v006, retrieved April 26, 2021

Mitigations.name: M1047
Mitigations.description: System audits can reveal anomalous behavior that may be caused by rootkits.

FGT1587.501.Name: Operator Network
FGT1587.501.Description: An adversary may create an operator network to facilitate applying techniques to a victim UE.

FGT1611.501.Name: Malicious privileged container VNF Shared Resource Access
FGT1611.501.Description: An adversary may compromise a target Virtual Network Function (VNF) to gain unauthorized access to the data from the underlying resources shared with other VNFs.

Detection.description: Audit application logs (NFVO, VIM).  Configuration management databases (CMDB) and other asset management systems may help with the detection of computer systems or network devices that should not exist on a network.
Monitor container creation, container start events
Monitor process activity on node, hosts and VNFs.
Monitor volume or storage modifications, attachment or read actions.

Procedure Examples.name: S0683
Procedure Examples.description: Peirates can deploy a pod that mounts its node’s root file system, then execute a command to create a reverse shell on the node

Procedure Examples.name: S0600
Procedure Examples.description: Doki was run through a deployed container

Procedure Examples.name: G0139
Procedure Examples.description: TeamTNT has deployed different types of containers into victim environments to facilitate execution.

Critical Assets.name: VNF and VNF Data
Critical Assets.description: Adversary may identify high value 5G network functions targets for its exploits

Mitigations.name: M1047
Mitigations.description: Scan images before deployment, and block those that are not in compliance with security policies. In Kubernetes environments, the admission controller can be used to validate images after a container deployment request is authenticated but before the container is deployed.

Mitigations.name: M1035
Mitigations.description: Limit communications with the container service to local Unix sockets or remote access via SSH. Require secure port access to communicate with the APIs over TLS by disabling unauthenticated access to the Docker API, Kubernetes API Server, and container orchestration web applications.

Mitigations.name: M1030
Mitigations.description: Deny direct remote access to internal systems through the use of network proxies, gateways, and firewalls.  Segment execution environment with node and network.

Mitigations.name: M1018
Mitigations.description: Enforce the principle of least privilege by limiting container dashboard access to only the necessary users.

FGT5026.Name: SIM cloning
FGT5026.Description: Adversary may clone a SIM card (namely the IMSI, credential stored therein) and use it fraudulently to obtain telecom service at the expense of the user of the device with that legitimate SIM card

Detection.description: Investigate unusual SIM card patterns.

Pre-Conditions.name: Access to SIM card
Pre-Conditions.description: Adversary needs physical access to SIM card.

Post-Conditions.name: Access to user credentials
Post-Conditions.description: With the cloned SIM card, adversary now has access to the victim’s permanent identifier (SUPI or IMSI) and master subscriber key Ki. Those can be used for unauthorized access to 5G network.

Procedure Examples.name: Duplicate captured SIM card
Procedure Examples.description: Adversary gets physical access to the victim SIM card and then uses smart card copying software to achieve duplication of the SIM card contents.

Critical Assets.name: Subscriber sensitive data
Critical Assets.description: SUPI, root key, home network public key etc.

References.name: Blog article, “Clone or Swap? SIM Card Vulnerabilities to Reckon With”

Mitigations.name: M1017
Mitigations.description: Only accept SIM cards from reputable manufacturers (MNOs)

Mitigations.name: M1018
Mitigations.description: User accounts management at the operator side

Mitigations.name: M1022
Mitigations.description: Restrict access to subscriber repository, which would allow SIM card changes

FGT1557.504.Name: Service Based Interface
FGT1557.504.Description: An adversary in the 5G core who  compromised a proxy or middlebox may position themselves between Network Functions (NFs) that are communicating via the Service Based Interfaces (SBI), in order to support follow-on behaviors such as  [Network Sniffing](/techniques/FGT1040) or [Transmitted Data Manipulation](/techniques/FGT1565.002).

Procedure Examples.name: Triple Handshake
Procedure Examples.description: (2014): if a TLS client connects to a malicious server and presents a client credential, the server can then impersonate the client at any other server that accepts the same credential. Concretely, the malicious server performs a man-in-the-middle attack on three successive handshakes between the honest client and server, and succeeds in impersonating the client on the third handshake. See e.g. [3SHAKE](/https://mitls.org/pages/attacks/3SHAKE)

Procedure Examples.name: SCP proxy as  AITM
Procedure Examples.description: An adversary in control of SCP can eavesdrop or alter data and signaling between e.g. AMF and UDM.

Critical Assets.name: 5G Core network services, control plane (provisioning) data, service discovery.
Critical Assets.description: There are many procedures that can be impacted if an adversary gets in the middle of a TLS connection between two functions on the SBI.

References.name: European Union Agency for Cybersecurity (ENISA): “ENISA Threat Landscape for 5G Networks” Report, December 2020.
3rd Generation Partnership Project (3GPP) TS 33.117, “Catalogue of general security assurance requirements (Release 17)”, v17.0.0, June 2021, clause 4.2.2.2
3GPP TS 33.310 “Network Domain Security (NDS); Authentication Framework (AF)”
G. Koien, "On Threats to the 5G Service Based Architecture", 2021.

Mitigations.name: FGM5095
Mitigations.description: TLS certificate thorough checking. Ensure that all certificates received over a connection are valid for the current server endpoint, and abort the handshake if they are not. In some usages, it may be simplest to refuse any change of certificates during renegotiation

Mitigations.name: FGM1557
Mitigations.description: Use TLS 1.3 or TLS 1.2 with only strong ciphersuites.

Mitigations.name: M1041
Mitigations.description: Use TLS 1.3 or TLS 1.2 with only strong ciphersuites

Mitigations.name: M1047
Mitigations.description: Audit NF configuration for interfaces, e.g. what version of TLS.

User Account authentication

R. Pell, S. Moschoyiannis, E. Panaousis, R. Heartfield, “Towards dynamic threat modelling in 5G core networks based on MITRE ATT&CK”,  October 2021

Mitigations.name: M1026
Mitigations.description: Privileged account management

FGT5012.002.Name: Locate UE: UE Measurement Reports
FGT5012.002.Description: An adversary may elicit location reports from UE that is bid down to less secure format or passively observes location reports from UE employing null encryption.

Detection.description: Subscriber transitions to less secure service.

Pre-Conditions.name: Permissive subscriber security profile OR system does not employ over-the-air encryption.
Pre-Conditions.description: Subscriber security profile must allow bidding down to less secure format OR system does not employ over-the-air encryption.

Post-Conditions.name: Subsequent attack
Post-Conditions.description: Geolocation can make electronic attack for degradation of service more effective, bidding down to defeat ID and traffic confidentiality more effective, and can expose subscriber to physical attack.

Procedure Examples.name: Self-location measurement
Procedure Examples.description: Victim UE is using a system with null encryption or is bid down to a less secure protocol. UE geolocation or geolocation measurement data is passively observed or, if bid down, actively ordered through illegitimate signaling.

Critical Assets.name: UE location
Critical Assets.description: UE/Subscriber geographical location

References.name: European Union Agency for Cybersecurity (ENISA): “ENISA Threat Landscape for 5G Networks” Report, December 2020.

Mitigations.name: FGM5006
Mitigations.description: Restrictive subscriber security profile. Do not use unencrypted systems. Set subscriber security profile to prohibit bidding down to less secure service.

Mitigations.name: FGM5096
Mitigations.description: Disable location on UE device. This is only a partial mitigation because location parameters can still be available from UE.

Mitigations.name: M1041
Mitigations.description: Avoid systems that employ null encryption. De-register when only NULL encryption is offered
