FGT1642.502.Name: UE
FGT1642.502.Description: An adversary may send a crafted signaling message to the UE to cause it to fail its attach procedure.

FGT1046.501.Name: Protocol Fingerprinting
FGT1046.501.Description: An adversary may perform network scanning to fingerprint network protocol by using CordScan.

FGT1499.503.Name: DOS a UE via gNB or NF signaling
FGT1499.503.Description: An adversary controlling a gNB or control plane or user plane core Network Function (NF) may manipulate signaling to result in DoS on one or more UEs.

Detection.description: Subscriber notifies provider of no or degraded service

Pre-Conditions.name: Compromise gNB or NF
Pre-Conditions.description: Adversary needs access to a fake or compromised gNB or a compromised NF.

Procedure Examples.name: DOS via gNB control (or fake UE)
Procedure Examples.description:
Adversary with a fake UE can send a De-registration request to the victim UE's gNB with the victim 5G-GUTI. Or , adversary with a fake gNB can send  Deregistration request to the victim UE. 
After the victim UE is either actively or passive bid down to less secure protocol, an adversary with a fake base station denies service by (1) issuing registration reject messages or other orders to deny radio access, or (2) posing as a legitimate base station, but not relaying traffic to or from the intended recipient.
Or, adversary with fake UE can try to register as the victim UE, and when the victim UE tries to RRC connect again, it will be rejected. See [2]

Procedure Examples.name: DOS via AMF control
Procedure Examples.description:
Adversary controlling AMF can cause authentication to fail or deny SMS service by deactivating SMS for a given SUPI [1]. Control of AMF can give an adversary the power to manipulate the AKA procedure between the AMF and any other UE, so that (at the simplest) the UE fails authentication and cannot get services.
Rogue or misconfigured NF modifies the registration accept message for legitimate subscribers to deny access to some or all services that are configured in their profile.

Procedure Examples.name: DOS via SEAF control
Procedure Examples.description: Adversary controlling SEAF may change the parameters exchanged back to the home network

Procedure Examples.name: DOS via SMF control
Procedure Examples.description: Adversary controlling SMF can release an existing PDU session or not create a new one; or send a  N4 Session Release request to UPF

Procedure Examples.name: DOS via UPF control
Procedure Examples.description: Adversary controlling UPF can send a report of PDU session inactivity, which results in de-activating the UE session. Or alter secondary authentication between DN AAA and SMF so it fails

Procedure Examples.name: DOS via AUSF control
Procedure Examples.description: Adversary controlling AUSF: produce incorrect AKA parameters or change data out of UDM

Procedure Examples.name: DOS via UDM control
Procedure Examples.description: Adversary controlling UDM: fail the SUPI de-concealing operation, UE key will be different and NAS SMC will fail (e.g., responding to SUCI deconcealment with an incorrect SUPI). See [3].

Procedure Examples.name: DOS via ARPF control
Procedure Examples.description:
Adversary controlling ARPF can
Alter the root key (K) or provide wrong root key for the UE
Generate wrong authentication vector (AV) during UE authentication procedure using EAP-AKA’ or 5G AKA.
Both will result in authentication failure for the UE.  [Section 6.1.3 of [4]]

Procedure Examples.name: DOS via UDR control
Procedure Examples.description: Adversary controlling UDR may give UDM incorrect security parameters, or remove UE authentication status.

Procedure Examples.name: DOS via PCF control
Procedure Examples.description: Adversary controlling PCF may return a very restrictive policy for that UE.

Procedure Examples.name: DOS via NSSF and NSSAAF control
Procedure Examples.description: Adversary controlling NSSF and NSSAAF may deny UE access to a slice by mishandling NSSAI (saying it's unavailable) or altering authentication params so that authentication procedure fails.

Procedure Examples.name: DOS via CHF control
Procedure Examples.description: Adversary controlling CHF may send a message to SMF to start PDU session release.

Procedure Examples.name: DOS via SMSF control
Procedure Examples.description: Adversary controlling SMSF may achieve DOS only on SMS for a given UE.

Procedure Examples.name: DOS via 5G EIR control
Procedure Examples.description: Adversary controlling 5G EIR can mark UE as stolen.

Procedure Examples.name: DOS via Home PLMN or visited PLMN SEPP
Procedure Examples.description: Adversary controlling home PLMN SEPP or visited PLMN SEPP can alter or discard registration request/response message and/or other signaling messages to deny access for a UE.

Critical Assets.name: Network services
Critical Assets.description: Communications is denied

References.name: European Union Agency for Cybersecurity (ENISA): “ENISA Threat Landscape for 5G Networks” Report, December 2020.
Hu, X. et al: “A Systematic Analysis Method for 5G Non-Access Stratum Signalling Security”, August 2019

3rd Generation Partnership Project (3GPP)  TR 33.926: “Security Assurance Specification (SCAS) threats and critical assets in 3GPP network product classes”, Technical Report, v17.3.0, December. 2021, clauses E.2.2.1
3rd Generation Partnership Project (3GPP)  TS 33.501: “Security architecture and procedures for 5G System”, Technical Specification, v17.6.0, June 2022

Mitigations.name: M1030
Mitigations.description: Implement industry standard core and edge network function security protection

Mitigations.name: FGM1506
Mitigations.description: Periodically authenticate NFs in the network to assess whether they have been compromised

FGT1599.505.Name: GTP-U Abuse
FGT1599.505.Description: An adversary-controlled UE may be used to send a GTP-U packet to UPF/PGW-U with a malicious payload in order to evade UPF/PGW-U routing controls to establish communications with a core NF.

FGT5024.Name: IAB Denial of Service
FGT5024.Description: Adversary may jam the wireless backhaul facility to disrupt the ability to connect to the network for all UEs or Integrated Access and Backhaul (IAB) nodes.

Detection.description: There are several tools, some using analysis after the fact, others test calls to network probes. Some tools use real time analysis of voice call characteristic – to detect VoIP calls illicitly tunneled into the operator network.
Use firewall to restrict unwanted traffic

The audio received by the base station from a simboxed
call will contain losses, indicating that the audio signal
has traveled over an Internet connection, while the audio from a legitimate call will not contain these losses. See [3]
Keeping track of SIM cards with strange usage pattern (e.g. bought but only used 1 hour) they may be part of a SIM box, and then blocking those SIM cards.

Pre-Conditions.name: SIM box equipment
Pre-Conditions.description: Adversary purchases a SIM box, SIM cards, and obtains an Internet connection

Procedure Examples.name: Adversary poses as legitimate carrier, to get to intercepts calls/ SMSs and re-route them.
Procedure Examples.description: Adversary/fraudster/SIM boxers are effectively acting as an unlicensed and unregulated telecommunications carrier (pretends to be a legitimate telecom provider). Adversary intercepts call and routes it via the Internet as a VoIP call, to the SIMbox (instead of via a regulated MNO interconnect). See [3], [5]

Procedure Examples.name: Adversary sells fraudulent international calling cards.
Procedure Examples.description: Adversary offers discounted call rates directly to end consumers, primarily through the sale of international calling cards. Such cards have a number that the user must dial before she can dial the recipient’s number; this number will route to a number provided by a VoIP provider that points to the SIMbox in the recipient’s country. See [3], [5]

Critical Assets.name: Operator revenue
Critical Assets.description: Revenue loss from international calls appearing as if they are domestic (often subsidized)

Critical Assets.name: Operator resources for SMS, voice calls’ quality of service is impacted
Critical Assets.description: A lot of calls are redirected to under provisioned cells, causing bad quality calls for legitimate subscribers

References.name: ENISA “Threat Landscape for 5G Networks Report” Nov 2019, section 5.2.
Masrub et. al.: “SIM boxing Problem: ALMADAR ALJADID Case Study”
Reaves et.al, “Boxed Out: Blocking Cellular Interconnect Bypass Fraud at the Network Edge”
Anne Josiane Kouam, Aline Carneiro Viana, Alain Tchana. “SIMBox bypass frauds in cellular networks: Strategies, evolution, detection, and future directions. Communications Surveys and Tutorials”
Mobile Ecosystem Forum, “Business SMS, SIM Farms and the Data Protection Risk”, whitepaper, 2020.

Mitigations.name: M1040
Mitigations.description:
Several tools exist to tag such SIM cards and reject calls from them.
Analyze and monitor call patterns, mobility patterns, and detect anomalies. See [4]

FGT5043.001.Name: Unauthorized access to core network function via token abuse: Exploit OAuth2 Scope
FGT5043.001.Description: Adversary exploits OAuth2.0 scope configuration using inadequate scope definitions during NF registration to gain unauthorized access to network functions in 5G networks.

FGT1203.502.Name: Baseband API
FGT1203.502.Description: An adversary may send specially crafted data to the UE's application processor's interface to the baseband API to execute malicious code. The adversary with a position on the UE to communicate to the baseband API may execute malicious code on the baseband processing system.

FGT1642.503.Name: AMF
FGT1642.503.Description: An adversary may send a crafted signaling message to the AMF to cause it to fail its service or attach request.

FGT1557.501.Name: Radio interface
FGT1557.501.Description: An adversary may position itself on the radio interface, to support follow-on behaviors such as  [Network Sniffing](/techniques/FGT1040) or [Transmitted Data Manipulation](/techniques/FGT1565.002).

Detection.description: UE measurements of received power levels from all base stations nearby, and their identifiers Reference clause 6.24 of [3]

Pre-Conditions.name: Permissive subscriber security profile OR system employs null integrity or encryption.
Pre-Conditions.description: Subscriber security profile must allow bidding down to less secure service OR system must employ null integrity or encryption.

Post-Conditions.name: Temporary loss of subscriber data confidentiality or integrity.
Post-Conditions.description: Transient technique. Works only as long as adversary-in-the-middle is able to retain connection.

Procedure Examples.name: Adversary-in-the-Middle on air interface for a given UE
Procedure Examples.description: The adversary employs a back to back gNB-UE combination. When UE security profile allows bidding down, adversary denies service to 5G, bids down victim UE to less secure protocol with illegitimate signaling, acts as a adversary-in-the-middle to intercept and possibly modify communication, and relays communication to and from intended recipient.

Procedure Examples.name: Adversary-in-the-Middle on air interface for any UE
Procedure Examples.description: Alternatively, if the 5G system employs null integrity or encryption, subscriber data traffic can be eavesdropped or modified in transit over the air interface

Procedure Examples.name: Adversary uses a fake base station to broadcast spoofed configuration messages to UEs nearby
Procedure Examples.description: Reference [3] (appendix B) contains a taxonomy of attacks against 5G UEs, passive and active. One concerns message attacks (fake MIB/SIB – Master Information Block/System Information Block)

Critical Assets.name: Subscriber signaling
Critical Assets.description: All signaling transmitted to and from subscriber can be intercepted in the clear

Critical Assets.name: UE location
Critical Assets.description: UE/subscriber geographical location can be intercepted.

Critical Assets.name: Subscriber traffic
Critical Assets.description: All data and voice transmitted to and from subscriber can be intercepted in the clear

References.name: European Union Agency for Cybersecurity (ENISA): “ENISA Threat Landscape for 5G Networks” Report, section 4.4, December 2020.
Hu, X. et al: “A Systematic Analysis Method for 5G Non-Access Stratum Signalling Security”, August 2019
3rd Generation Partnership Project (3GPP) TR 33.809: “Study on  5G security enhancements against False Base Stations (FBS)”, Technical Report, v0.18.0, February 2022.

FGT1588.501.Name: Obtain Capabilities: Radio Network Functions
FGT1588.501.Description: An adversary may obtain radio network function needed to attack target victim UEs.

FGT5018.002.Name: Vandalism of Network Infrastructure: Radio Access Hardware
FGT5018.002.Description: An adversary uses unrestricted access to exploit, damage, or destroy Radio Access hardware that lack adequate security

Detection.description: Event logs recording user activities, exceptions, faults and information security events should be produced, kept and regularly reviewed. Additional considerations: development of use-case specific alert rules, integration and correlation of data at all levels (network, application), integration and correlation with service provider-level monitoring mechanisms.

Pre-Conditions.name: Improper physical security of radio access hardware
Pre-Conditions.description: Despite the virtualized structure of the 5G network and all involved network functions, there will be a strong dependency on the physical infrastructure, especially in the initial migration/hybrid 5G deployments.

Post-Conditions.name: Service unavailability
Post-Conditions.description: Destruction or damage of these assets may cause unavailability of resources

Post-Conditions.name: Information destruction
Post-Conditions.description: Destruction or damage of these assets may cause information destruction

Procedure Examples.name: Physical sabotage/vandalism of the network infrastructure
Procedure Examples.description: Classified as a deliberate physical attack, this threat relates to actions taken by actors aimed at destroying, disabling or stealing physical assets supporting the 5G Network. A physical attack to 5G critical assets may disrupt, interfere and ultimately cause unavailability of the network service. Despite the existence of physical protection mechanisms (e.g., physical surveillance and surveillance cameras, security locks, security guards), physical breaches and insider threat attacks may still occur.

Critical Assets.name: Radio access hardware (gNB)
Critical Assets.description: RAN-CU & DU, C-RAN MEC and mmWave equipment

References.name: European Union Agency for Cybersecurity (ENISA): “ENISA Threat Landscape for 5G Networks” Report, page 202, December 2020.
El-Shorbagy, A.-moniem. “5G Technology and the Future of Architecture”. Procedia Computer Science, (2021), volume 182, p121–131.

Mitigations.name: FGM5005
Mitigations.description: Sites should be provided with a full set of physical and environmental controls aimed to assure access control, monitoring, continuity of operations and protection against vandalism.

FGT5012.007.Name: Locate UE: Silent or spoofed paging
FGT5012.007.Description: Adversary sends spoofed or silent paging messages to a UE and deduces the UE's location from the responses of that UE

Detection.description: Inspect network traffic and watch for unauthorized changes as the packets move through the interfaces.
Legitimate UEs notify their service provider about DoS attack and abnormal session terminations.

Pre-Conditions.name: Weakened or disabled integrity protection
Pre-Conditions.description: See [FGT5009.002](/techniques/FGT5009.002)

Post-Conditions.name: UE data manipulation
Post-Conditions.description: Both UE signaling and user plane data communication with network will be impacted. This can cause DoS attack for legitimate subscribers.

Procedure Examples.name: Data manipulation on the non-SBI
Procedure Examples.description:
If gNB is compromised or misconfigured, CP and UP data can be manipulated by adversary on N2, N3 and Xn interfaces. Clause D.2.2 of [1], 5.3.3 of [2]

If AMF or SMF is compromised or misconfigured, CP data can be manipulated by adversary on N2 and N4 interfaces. Clauses 5.5.2 & 9.9 of [2]

If UPF is compromised or misconfigured, UP data can be manipulated by adversary on N3 interface. Clause D.2.2 of [1], 9.3 of [2]

Procedure Examples.name: Data manipulation on the SBI
Procedure Examples.description:
If NF is compromised or misconfigured, CP data can be manipulated on SBI interface. Clause 13.1 of [2] (DoS attack) 

If SCP is compromised or misconfigured, CP data can be manipulated on SBI. Clause 5.9.2.4 of [2] (DoS attack)

An access token may be manipulated to gain unauthorized access to another NF. [FGT5011](/techniques/FGT5011) 

A rogue or misconfigured AMF can obtain the temporary UE ID (5G-GUTI or 5G-S-TMSI) during UE registration and service request and later use the ID to spoof signaling messages to retrieve sensitive subscriber information. Clauses 4.2.2.2.2 & 4.2.3.2 of [4]. (Unauthorized access)

Note: This attack is possible in both non-roaming and roaming scenarios.

Procedure Examples.name: Data manipulation on roaming/interconnect
Procedure Examples.description:
If SEPP or IPX component is compromised or misconfigured, CP data can be manipulated by adversary on N32 interface. Clauses 13.1, 13.2 of [2]

If UPF is compromised or misconfigured, UP data can be manipulated by adversary on N9 interface. Clause 9.9 of [2]

If AMF or MME is compromised or misconfigured, CP data can be manipulated by adversary on N26 interface. Clause K.2.1 of [1], 8.4 of [2]

Critical Assets.name: UE data
Critical Assets.description: Any of the subscriber user plane data sourced or destined to the UE

Critical Assets.name: UE signaling
Critical Assets.description: Any of the signaling traffic sourced or destined to the UE

References.name: 3GPP TR33.926 “Security Assurance Specification (SCAS) threats and critical assets in 3GPP network product classes.”
3GPP TS33.501 “Security architecture and procedures for 5G System.”
3GPP TS 23.501 “System architecture for the 5G System (5GS)”
3GPP TS 23.502 “Procedures for the 5G System (5GS)”

Mitigations.name: FGM1557
Mitigations.description: Use integrity (IPSec) on all non-SBI interfaces, TLS 1.3 on all SBI interfaces including roaming interfaces (e.g. N32).

FGT1562.501.Name: Bid down UE
FGT1562.501.Description: An adversary may employ a false base station to bid down (downgrade) the victim UE to a less secure Radio Access Network in order to exploit vulnerabilities in that network.

Detection.description: At the UE side, the UE can tell that there is a 5G cell site that it can hear, but if it eventually gets connected to a 4G cell site, then it may have suffered a bidding down attack

Pre-Conditions.name: Fake base station with strong signal and UE system
Pre-Conditions.description: Attacker has procured a UE and gNB under its control, and the victim UE is nearby

Procedure Examples.name: Fake gNB redirects UE to 4G.
Procedure Examples.description:
UEs tend to attach to gNBs which have better signal condition than the gNB the UE is currently attached. Fake gNB with stronger signal strength than legitimate gNBs sends RRC redirection that is not integrity protected.
RRCRelease message sent without integrity (so UE can’t check), has the instruction for the UE to attach to a 4G cell instead (i.e, RedirectInfo as E-UTRA Absolute Radio Frequency Channel Number (E-ARFCN)

Critical Assets.name: User data
Critical Assets.description: Data that the UE sends to/from the network (including identifiers) is at risk of being eavesdropped or tampered with.

References.name: S.P. Rao, S. Holtmanns, T. Aura: “Threat modeling framework for mobile communication systems”, May 2020

Mitigations.name: FGM5002
Mitigations.description:
UE should discard RRC redirection that is  not integrity protected, and go search for other gNBs. UE should only accept to register to networks that require mutual auth and strong encryption, also integrity protection of user plane.
[reference](https://www.scribd.com/document/350156530/forcing-targeted-lte-cellphone-into-unsafe-network)

Mitigations.name: FGM5092
Mitigations.description: UE warns user of lower security network (and the user can take action to limit data or type of data, or to disconnect).

Mitigations.name: FGM5097
Mitigations.description: Set security profile to prohibit bidding down to less secure service.

FGT1600.501.Name: Radio Interface
FGT1600.501.Description: An adversary may alter network signaling so as to disable encryption over the radio interface, thus allowing for eavesdropping of user data or signaling on that interface.

Detection.description: Inspect radio traffic and watch for unauthorized changes as the packets move through the interfaces.
Check configuration changes in gNB, SMF, AMF; Configuration audits by OSS/BSS.

Pre-Conditions.name: Rogue or misconfigured AMF or SMF or gNB
Pre-Conditions.description:
A rogue gNB may be required to change the UE’s CP and UP supported algorithms to NULL. It’s easier to achieve control over a gNB than over the AMF or SMF itself. But then if the AMF and SMF are not rogue just not configured to do these additional checks, then control over a rogue gNB is sufficient.
This attack is possible with only control over the AMF, in which case the algorithm for CP and UP protection is changed to NULL.

Post-Conditions.name: UE data unprotected on air interface
Post-Conditions.description:
Control Plane: All UE signaling data may be revealed if both NAS and AS CP (RRC) algorithms are weakened.

User Plane: Subscriber (user plane) data may be revealed if AS UP algorithms are weakened.

Procedure Examples.name: Fake or misconfigured base station
Procedure Examples.description:
Adversary (e.g. with fake gNB) intentionally configures NULL encryption algorithm to have highest priority in gNB. These algorithms are sent to the UE in the (Access Stratum) AS Security Mode Command. Normally the activation of algorithms for the AS is done by the gNB based on that policy received from the SMF, but a fake gNB can ignore the SMF. Clauses 6.7.3 & D.1 of [2].

Adversary with control over a legitimate gNB, and who currently serves the UE, tells the SMF that the UE Control Plane (CP) and User Plane (UP) policy is NULL encryption, and the (legitimate but not correctly implemented) SMF doesn’t check that against the locally-stored UE UP policy and lets the CP and UP data be transmitted with NULL encryption. Clause 6.6.1 of [2]

Procedure Examples.name: Rogue or misconfigured SMF
Procedure Examples.description:
Adversary makes the unauthorized change in the SMF CP and UP local policy to enable NULL encryption for CP & UP traffic.
Alternatively, adversary exploits an SMF that is not implemented to check (for every UE it serves) that the algorithm received from gNB (which may be compromised or fake) matches the local policy. That local policy in turn should be checked that it is the same as the UE policy stored in the UDM. Any of these failures can result in the SMF enabling the CP and UP traffic over the radio interface to use NULL encryption.

Procedure Examples.name: Rogue or misconfigured AMF non-roaming
Procedure Examples.description:
Adversary with control over AMF (or control over the configuration of AMF) can affect UE procedures such as NAS Security Mode Command, such that the UE's NAS data is not protected, i.e. prioritize NULL algorithm for either NAS encryption or integrity.
 
This can be followed by another attack behavior whereby eavesdropping can be done over the air interface for data and signaling. Clauses 5.3.2 and 5.5.1 of [2]

Procedure Examples.name: Rogue or misconfigured AMF during roaming/handover
Procedure Examples.description:
Compromised source AMF sends incorrect UE context information to legitimate target AMF during either (a) Initial registration and roaming or (b) Handover (N2 based). 
The source AMF sends NULL  encryption algorithm information as part of the “UEContextTransfer” (initial registration and roaming) or “CreateUEContext” (N2 handover) service request messages. All UE data will be sent in cleartext after registration or handover is completed. Clauses 4.2.2.2.2, 4.9.1.3.1 and 5.2.2.1 of [3. ] The element in the UE context is the ueSecurityCapability which the rogue AMF sets to NULL only.

Procedure Examples.name: Rogue or misconfigured AMF/MME during EPS roaming/handover
Procedure Examples.description:
Compromised source MME/AMF sends incorrect UE context information to legitimate target AMF during EPS to 5GS handover and roaming with and without N26 interface.

Source AMF sends NULL encryption algorithm information as part of the “UEContextTransfer” or 
“RelocateUEContext” service request messages. All UE data will be sent in clear text after roaming or handover is completed. Clauses 4.11.1.2.2.2, 4.11.1.3.3, 4.11.2.3 and 5.2.2.1 of [3] The element in the UE context is the ueSecurityCapability which the rogue AMF sets to NULL only.

Critical Assets.name: UE data
Critical Assets.description: UE and subscriber (user plane) data privacy.

Critical Assets.name: UE signaling
Critical Assets.description: UE signaling data privacy

References.name: 3GPP TR 33.926 “Security Assurance Specification (SCAS) threats and critical assets in 3GPP network product classes”.
3GPP TS 33.501 “Security architecture and procedures for 5G System”.
3GPP TS 23.502 “Procedures for the 5G System (5GS)”.

Mitigations.name: M1041
Mitigations.description: Ensure gNB implementation and SMF implementations are both checking the UE CP and UP security policy against the most trustworthy source and taking action to not enable NULL encryption except for emergency calls

Mitigations.name: M1018
Mitigations.description: Network element security safeguards for gNBs, AMFs and SMFs. Includes measures in clause 5.3.4 of [2] for gNBs (e.g. software updates, OA&M access security, secure boot)

Mitigations.name: M1051
Mitigations.description: Network element security safeguards for gNBs, AMFs and SMFs. Includes measures in clause 5.3.4 of [2] for gNBs (e.g. software updates, OA&M access security, secure boot)

Mitigations.name: M1046
Mitigations.description: Network element security safeguards for gNBs, AMFs and SMFs. Includes measures in clause 5.3.4 of [2] for gNBs (e.g. software updates, OA&M access security, secure boot)

Mitigations.name: M1031
Mitigations.description: Implement network intrusion prevention methods

Mitigations.name: M1043
Mitigations.description: Implement credential access protection methods

FGT5012.006.Name: Locate UE: NAS Exploit
FGT5012.006.Description: An adversary may geolocate a UE by modifying Non-Access Stratum (NAS) signaling.

Detection.description: Operator standard means to detect presence of fake gNBs. gNB radio signals (sent to all UEs to enable them to select gNB and connect) are received and reported by UEs to the operator, who can then run cross checks with the signals that the UEs should have received if all gNBs nearby were legitimate.

Pre-Conditions.name: Control of fake gNB in the area where the victim UE may be located.
Pre-Conditions.description: Adversary must install a fake gNB that it can control what messages it sends to UEs.

Pre-Conditions.name: Control of fake UE  in the NAS SMC attack.
Pre-Conditions.description: Adversary must acquire a fake UE to achieve the NAS SMC attack.

Procedure Examples.name: Replay of NAS message
Procedure Examples.description: Adversary eavesdrops one NAS message from the legitimate network (the Auth_Req (R, AUTN), or the NAS Security Mode Command (SMC)), then replays that NAS message whenever it wants to check whether the victim UE is nearby, since the type of error (or response, in the case of SMC) received from the responder indicates whether it's the victim UE or not. Thus, adversary can probe for UE’s presence in a that cell, which leads to coarse location data. See [1].

Critical Assets.name: UE location
Critical Assets.description: UE/Subscriber geographical location, coarse or fine-grained

References.name: X. Hu et.al. “A Systematic Analysis Method for 5G Non-Access Stratum Signalling Security”, IEEE Access, August 2019.

FGT5019.002.Name: Subscriber Profile Identifier Discovery: Intercept bid-down SUPI
FGT5019.002.Description: An adversary may intercept the UE permanent identifier (SUPI) from a UE that is bid down to a less secure protocol.

Detection.description: UE transitions to less secure service

Pre-Conditions.name: Permissive user security profile
Pre-Conditions.description: User security profile must allow bidding down.

Pre-Conditions.name: Bid down operation successful
Pre-Conditions.description: Denying service to 5G and bidding down (e.g. from a fake or compromised base station) must have occurred for this 5G UE.

Post-Conditions.name: Target association
Post-Conditions.description: Allows an adversary to identify UE as target of interest for geolocation, degradation of service, loss of traffic confidentiality, or physical attack.

Procedure Examples.name: Obtain permanent UE identifier IMSI from bid-down UE
Procedure Examples.description: Adversary with fake or compromised base station sends an Identity Request message to the UE to get back the IMSI. This occurs after the UE has been bid down from 5G.

Critical Assets.name: UE identifier
Critical Assets.description: Unique and non-transient user identity

References.name: European Union Agency for Cybersecurity (ENISA): “ENISA Threat Landscape for 5G Networks” Report, December 2020.

Mitigations.name: FGM5006
Mitigations.description: Restrictive user security profile can dictate that the UE will refuse to networks that are not 5G. The prevention of bidding-down is achieved via user security profile stored in the UE.

FGT1600.502.Name: Network Interfaces
FGT1600.502.Description: An adversary may weaken or disable encryption on Non-SBI, SBI, and Roaming interfaces, enabling eavesdropping on user data or signaling.

Detection.description: Inspect network traffic and watch for unauthorized changes
Check configuration changes in gNB and all core NFs; Configuration audits by OSS/BSS.

Pre-Conditions.name: Rogue or misconfigured AMF or SMF or gNB or UPF or SEPP or MME or any other core NF
Pre-Conditions.description: Adversary must have access to the network components to cause the attacks

Post-Conditions.name: UE data unprotected on network interfaces
Post-Conditions.description:
Control Plane: All UE signaling data may be revealed if IPSec and TLS are disabled.

User Plane: Subscriber (user plane) data may be revealed if IPSec is disabled. 

UE CP & UP data can be sniffed. [FGT1040](/techniques/FGT1040)

Procedure Examples.name: Compromised or misconfigured gNB
Procedure Examples.description: A rogue or misconfigured gNB can disable IPSec encryption or use a weak IPSec encryption algorithm on backhaul interfaces such as N2, N3 and Xn. Then it can launch other attacks. Clause D.2.2 of [1], clause 5.3.2 of [2].

Procedure Examples.name: Compromised or misconfigured AMF
Procedure Examples.description: A rogue or misconfigured AMF can disable IPSec encryption or use a weak IPSec encryption algorithm on N2 and N26 interfaces. Then it can launch other attacks. Clause K.2.1 of [1], clause 5.5.1  of [2]

Procedure Examples.name: Compromised or misconfigured UPF
Procedure Examples.description: A rogue or misconfigured UPF can disable IPSec encryption or use a weak IPSec encryption algorithm on N3, N4 and N9 interfaces. Then it can launch other attacks. Clause L.2.1 of [1]

Procedure Examples.name: Compromised or misconfigured SMF
Procedure Examples.description: A rogue or misconfigured SMF can disable IPSec encryption or use a weak IPSec encryption algorithm on N4 interface. Then it can launch other attacks. Clause 9.9 of [2]

Procedure Examples.name: Compromised or misconfigured NF
Procedure Examples.description:
A rogue or misconfigured AMF can disable the TLS encryption or use a weak TLS encryption algorithm to another NF including the SCP. Then it can launch other attacks to gain unauthorized access to network services. Clause 13.1 of [2]

If SCP is rogue or misconfigured, it can force TLS connections to all NFs to be unencrypted or use weak encryptions for all. Clause 5.9.2.4 of [2]

Procedure Examples.name: Compromised or misconfigured SEPP or IPX component
Procedure Examples.description:
A rogue or misconfigured SEPP can disable TLS encryption or use a weak TLS encryption algorithm on N32-c interface or N32-f interface or both.

A rogue or misconfigured SEPP can disable JWE encryption or use a weak encryption algorithm when PRINS is used on N32-f. Then it can launch other attacks. Clauses 13.1 and 13.2 of [2]

Procedure Examples.name: Compromised or misconfigured MME/AMF, or UPF.
Procedure Examples.description:
A rogue or misconfigured AMF/MME can disable IPSec encryption or use a weak IPSec encryption algorithm on N26 interface. Then it can launch other attacks. Clause K.2.1 of [1], 8.4 of [2].

A rogue or misconfigured UPF can disable IPSec encryption or use a weak IPSec encryption algorithm on the N9 interface between home PLMN UPF and visited PLMN UPF. See clause 9.9, 13.1 and 13.2 of [2]

Mitigations.name: M1041
Mitigations.description: Ensure strong encryption is used in all non-SBI, SBI and roaming/interconnect interfaces. That is, TLS should be used in all SBI, N32-c and N32-f and PRINS in N32-f when TLS is not used.

FGT5019.001.Name: Subscriber Profile Identifier Discovery: Intercept Home Network via SUCI
FGT5019.001.Description: An adversary may intercept unencrypted radio transmissions of a UE's SUCI to identify the home network of the UE.

Pre-Conditions.name: Ability to receive SUCI over the air
Pre-Conditions.description: Attacker requires sufficient signal to noise and interference ratio

Post-Conditions.name: Target association
Post-Conditions.description: When home network is unusual (e.g., US home network in Afghanistan), allows attacker to identify UE as target of interest for geolocation, degradation of service, loss of traffic confidentiality, or physical attack.

Procedure Examples.name: Intercept home network over the radio interface
Procedure Examples.description: Receive SUCI and extract the field “home network identifier”, which is never concealed.

Critical Assets.name: UE privacy

Mitigations.name: FGM1505
Mitigations.description: When the subscriber affiliation is reflected in the home network identifier (part of subscriber identifier), and would benefit from not being sent in the clear, the subscriber's provider (home network) should be a proxy mobile network operator - whose identifier does not reveal the true affiliation of the subscriber.

Detection.description: Monitor for suspicious account behavior across cloud services that share account.  Logon session logs and meta data helps determine if the session was an authorized activity.

Monitor user account authentication activity.  Monitor the activity of cloud accounts to detect abnormal or malicious behavior, such as accessing information outside of the normal function of the account or account usage at atypical hours.  Repeated attempts may be indictive of password guessing or brute force password cracking.  Password policies supporting lockout requiring administrative reset may help.

Mitigations.name: M1032
Mitigations.description: Use multi-factor authentication for cloud and virtualization OSS accounts used for VNF deployments, especially privileged accounts.

Mitigations.name: M1027
Mitigations.description: Ensure that cloud accounts, particularly privileged accounts, have complex, unique passwords across all systems on the network. Passwords and access keys should be rotated regularly. This limits the amount of time credentials can be used to access resources if a credential is compromised without your knowledge. Rotate access keys regularly.

Mitigations.name: M1026
Mitigations.description: Review privileged cloud account permission levels routinely to look for those that could allow an adversary to gain wide access.  Unbound administrative access to accounts should be be discouraged when creating account policies.

Mitigations.name: M1018
Mitigations.description: Periodically review user accounts and remove those that are inactive or unnecessary. Limit the ability for user accounts to create additional accounts.

Mitigations.name: M1017
Mitigations.description: Applications may send push notifications to verify a login as a form of multi-factor authentication (MFA). Train users to only accept valid push notifications and to report suspicious push notifications.

FGT5027.Name: Spoof network slice identifier
FGT5027.Description: An adversary controlling a Network Function (NF) or slice can gain access to a different network slice data by interacting with other NFs.

Detection.description: Check logs of requests/responses at the shared NF. E.g., each entry should contain UE ID (SUPI), NF consumer that requested it, slice Ids of both.

Pre-Conditions.name: Slice identifier was discovered
Pre-Conditions.description: See [FGT5028](/techniques/FGT5028)

Pre-Conditions.name: Two slices share one common NF
Pre-Conditions.description: This is common in practice

Pre-Conditions.name: NRF does not check requester slice identifier and the target (consumer) slice identifier.
Pre-Conditions.description: This is implicit in the standards that do not mandate this check.

Procedure Examples.name: Adversary NF in one slice uses guessed slice identifier of another slice to gain unauthorized access to resources in that slice.
Procedure Examples.description:
A malicious NF and/or malicious slice can use the guessed identifier Slice Differentiator (SD) to gain unauthorized information or resource access to a different slice. The NF asks the NRF for an OAuth token for an NF in that other slice. The reason is the requested SD (actually, the entire NSSAI) is included in the OAuth token without verification whether requester is allowed access to it. The NRF issues that OAuth token because it is for a producer NF that serves both the requester’s slice and the targeted (victim) slice. 
This seems to be a poor approach to access control- one that relies on knowing an identifier, and so access is given if that identifier—presumably kept secret—is found out. See section 3.1.3.1 of [1].

Critical Assets.name: Confidentiality of slice-specific resources
Critical Assets.description: UE (served by that slice) related information. Slice specific configuration – e.g. what NFs are part of it and SLAs of the slice.

Critical Assets.name: Core NFs
Critical Assets.description: The functionality of any core NF that is shared between slices (AMF, SMF, PCF,.. )

FGT1498.501.Name: Flooding of core network component
FGT1498.501.Description: An adversary-controlled UE may send high volumes of signaling messages to core network functions in order to cause a denial of service.

Detection.description:
Application layer DoS attack detection mechanism can be used to detect repeated attempt of UE attach-detach cycle within a short period.
NAS-MM (Non-access stratum Mobility Mgmt) app layer proxy with UE request rate limiting capability.

Post-Conditions.name: AMF service will not be available to legitimate users during attack.
Post-Conditions.description: If AMF services are down, all services for the existing UEs which use NAS layer will not be available. For example: mobility, session management (QoS etc.), PDU session set up / tear down, SMS over NAS, location management. [Section 8.2.2.1 of [2]

Procedure Examples.name: Control plane signaling storm from (at least) one malicious UE
Procedure Examples.description:
Because network slices and network functions can be shared, malicious UE can create control plane storms.

AMF Message Flooding for a shared slice with shared NFs:
(1) An initial AMF validates if the user (UE) is allowed to access the subscribed S-NSSAI: AMF contacts the UDM to request the UE’s Slice Selection Subscription data.  The initial UDM may contact the UDR for the UE's Slice Selection Subscription data, then provides the data to the AMF.
(2) During the t0 to t-delta time interval that it takes to perform (1), the UE drops the initial AMF then re-attaches to the AMF, restarting the validation.
(3) The UE recursively performs (2), which recursively performs (1), creating a "UE-AMF-UDM-UDR-AMF" message storm sandwiched in between an "Attach-Detach" storm.
(4) Since this is a shared slice with shared NFs, the control plane storm (Attach-UE-AMF-UDM-UDR-AMF-Detach-Attach-recursively repeat) creates a DoS condition.

Critical Assets.name: Network services (AMF)
Critical Assets.description: AMF functionality serving the UEs should be available.

Mitigations.name: FGM5498
Mitigations.description:
Employ a firewall or other rate control box on the N2 interface [from RAN to AMF]

(May not be available in the market). Employ a NAS-MM (Non-access stratum Mobility Mgmt) application layer proxy at the edge of the network, having the capability to limit UE request rate.
In addition, SCP can act as load balancer between the service consumer (AMF) and service producer (UDM). (Annex E of [2])

FGT1040.501.Name: Radio interface
FGT1040.501.Description: An adversary may eavesdrop on unencrypted subscriber data on the air interface.

Detection.description: UE transitions to less secure service. UE responds to requests that were not sent by legitimate network.

Pre-Conditions.name: Permissive subscriber security profile OR system employs null encryption.
Pre-Conditions.description: Subscriber security profile must allow bidding down to less secure service OR system must employ null encryption.

Post-Conditions.name: Temporary loss of subscriber data confidentiality.
Post-Conditions.description: Transient technique. Works only as long as adversary is able to retain connection.

Procedure Examples.name: Eavesdrop on air interface for a given UE
Procedure Examples.description:
The adversary employs a back to back fake gNB-UE combination. When UE security profile allows bidding down, adversary denies service to 5G, bids down victim UE to less secure protocol with illegitimate signaling, orders the UE to transmit with no or weak encryption, acts as an adversary-in-the-middle to intercept communication, and relays communication to and from intended recipient. 
Subscriber location can be derived from measurement reports by rogue gNB. Reference [2] and section 6.7.4 of [3], and [4].

Procedure Examples.name: Eavesdrop on air interface for any UE
Procedure Examples.description: Alternatively, if the 5G system employs null encryption, subscriber data traffic can be collected in the clear ([1]). Subscriber location can be sent by the UE to the network or vice versa

FGT5009.001.Name: Weaken Integrity: Radio Interface
FGT5009.001.Description: An adversary may alter or spoof network signaling so as to enable the NULL integrity algorithm thus allowing for manipulation of user data or signaling over the radio interface, for example to redirect traffic.

Detection.description:
Radio traffic content
Inspect radio traffic and watch for unauthorized changes as the packets move through the interfaces.
Check configuration changes in gNB, SMF, AMF. Configuration audits by OSS/BSS

Pre-Conditions.name: Rogue or misconfigured AMF or SMF or gNB or MME
Pre-Conditions.description:
A rogue gNB may be required to change the UE’s CP & UP supported algorithms to NULL. It’s easier to achieve control over a gNB than over the AMF or SMF itself. But then if the AMF and SMF are not rogue just not configured to do these additional checks, then control over a rogue gNB is sufficient.
This attack is possible with only control over the AMF, in which case the algorithm for CP and UP protection may be changed to NULL.

Post-Conditions.name: UE data not integrity protected on air interface
Post-Conditions.description:
Control Plane (CP): All UE signaling data may be tampered with if both NAS and AS CP (i.e., RRC) algorithms are weakened. 

User Plane (UP): Subscriber (user) data may be tampered with if AS UP algorithms are weakened.

As a result, subscriber data session does not get setup (DoS attack) or gets interrupted during an active session.

Procedure Examples.name: Fake or misconfigured base station
Procedure Examples.description:
Adversary (e.g. with fake gNB) intentionally configures NULL integrity algorithm to have highest priority in gNB. These algorithms are sent to the UE in the Access Stratum (AS) Security Mode Command (SMC). Normally the activation of algorithms for the AS is done by the gNB based on that policy received from the SMF, but a fake gNB can ignore the SMF. Sections 6.7.3 & D.1 of [2].

Adversary with control over a legitimate gNB, and who currently serves the UE, tells the SMF that the UE Control Plane (CP) and User Plane (UP) policy is NULL integrity, and the (legit but not correctly implemented) SMF doesn’t check that against the locally-configured UE CP & UP policy and lets the CP and UP data use NULL integrity. Section 6.6.1 of [2]

Procedure Examples.name: Rogue or misconfigured SMF
Procedure Examples.description:
Adversary makes the unauthorized change in the SMF CP & UP local policy to enable NULL integrity for CP & UP traffic.
Alternatively, adversary exploits an SMF that is not implemented to check (for every UE it serves) that the algorithm received from gNB- (which may be compromised or fake) matches the local policy. That local policy in turn should be checked that it is the same as the UE policy stored in the UDM. Any of these failures can result in the SMF enabling the CP and UP traffic over the radio interface to use NULL integrity.

Procedure Examples.name: Rogue or misconfigured AMF non-roaming
Procedure Examples.description:
Adversary with control over AMF (or control over the configuration of AMF) can affect UE procedures such as NAS Security Mode Command, such that the UE's NAS data is not protected, i.e. prioritize NULL algorithm for either NAS encryption or integrity. Section K.2.3.3. of [1]. 
This can be followed by another attack behavior whereby data manipulation can be done over the air interface for user plane and signaling data. Sections 5.3.2, 5.3.3 & 5.5.1, 5.5.2 of [2]

Procedure Examples.name: Rogue or misconfigured AMF during roaming/handover
Procedure Examples.description:
Compromised source AMF sends incorrect UE context information to legitimate target AMF during
Initial registration & roaming or
Handover (N2 based)

Source AMF sends null integrity algorithm information as part of the “UEContextTransfer” (initial registration & roaming) or “CreateUEContext” (N2 handover) service request messages. All UE data will be sent without integrity protection after registration or handover is completed. Sections 4.2.2.2.2, 4.9.1.3.1 & 5.2.2.1 of [3] The element in the UE context is the ueSecurityCapability which the rogue AMF sets to NULL only.

Procedure Examples.name: Rogue or misconfigured AMF/MME during EPS roaming/handover
Procedure Examples.description:
Compromised source MME/AMF sends incorrect UE context information to legitimate target AMF during EPS to 5GS handover and roaming with and without N26 interface.

Source AMF sends NULL integrity algorithm information as part of the “UEContextTransfer” or 
“RelocateUEContext” service request messages. All UE data will be sent without integrity protection  after roaming or handover is completed. Sections 4.11.1.2.2.2, 4.11.1.3.3, 4.11.2.3 & 5.2.2.1 of [3] The element in the UE context is the ueSecurityCapability which the rogue AMF sets to NULL only.

FGT1499.502.Name: Trigger fraud alert to deny service
FGT1499.502.Description: An adversary may trigger a fraud alert by sending fake registrations on behalf of a given UE

Detection.description: Subscriber contacts service provider to determine why service is denied.

Pre-Conditions.name: A valid IMSI/SUPI or SUCI must be intercepted by attacker.
Pre-Conditions.description: There are several methods to achieve this by capturing over the air messages using a wireless sniffer.

Post-Conditions.name: Sustained denial of service
Post-Conditions.description: Denial of service continues until service provider is convinced there is no fraud.

Procedure Examples.name: Adversary replays registration attempt for a victim UE to a gNB much further away (“geographically impossible”).
Procedure Examples.description:
Adversary may capture a registration attempt for a given UE, then replay it right away to a gNB much further away – so that the network receives two registrations at about the same time e.g. from two regions far away: New York and Georgia.  
The network will trigger a fraud alert. Thus, RAN access may be denied to that victim UE because of the attempted simultaneous registrations at geographically impossible locations.

Critical Assets.name: Assured user communications
Critical Assets.description: Communications is denied

FGT5012.005.Name: Locate UE: Shared Network Function in slice
FGT5012.005.Description: An adversary uses a legitimate access token for a shared Network Function (NF) to get location info of a user of a different slice.

Detection.description: Regularly audit applications and interface messaging logs. Check logs of requests/responses at the shared NF. E.g., each entry should contain SUPI, NF consumer that requested it, slice IDs of both.

Pre-Conditions.name: Access shared NF in a different slice
Pre-Conditions.description:
Two slices share one common NF that is able to get UE location info. Adversary has control of one slice or at least a NF in that slice -- where said NF is allowed to talk to the AMF.

The following core NFs can legitimately ask for or obtain directly the location of a UE (some granularity): AMF, UDM, NEF, NWDAF, GMLC, LMF. The following core NFs can only get limited/coarse location: SMF, UPF, PCF.

Post-Conditions.name: UE’s location is tracked by rogue NF
Post-Conditions.description: Target slice information is leaked, slice confidentiality is breached due to sharing the NF between slices.

Procedure Examples.name: Malicious NF belonging to compromised Network Slice gets an access token for the target AMF, which serves both target slice and compromised slice.
Procedure Examples.description: Malicious NF of a compromised slice gets access token for a shared AMF, but then asks AMF for the location of a UE in the target slice. The AMF checks that the authorization (OAuth) token is ok, which it is, but does not check that the UE ID is served by target slice, while the requester NF is from compromised slice. Section 3.1.5 of [1].

Critical Assets.name: UE location

Mitigations.name: FGM5012
Mitigations.description: Cross check requested SUPI is served by (belongs to) the slice ID (NSSAI) of the consumer NF (and presented in the authorization Token). That is, this attack could be mitigated if the shared network function (NF service producer) checks the SUPI in a service request and the requesting NF service consumer are being served by the same slice. (3GPP SA3 is investigating if 3GPP specifications allow for such check)

Pre-Conditions.name: Compromise of core consumer NF
Pre-Conditions.description: For NF discovery service, 23.502 lists these consumers: AMF, SMF, PCF, NEF, NSSF, SMSF, AUSF, CHF, NRF, NWDAF, I-CSCF, SCSCF, IMS-AS, SCP, UDM, AF, DCCF, MBSF, 5G DDNMF, TSCTSF.

Procedure Examples.name: An adversary in control of a network function asks the NRF for a token for a guessed SD until a legitimate response is received.
Procedure Examples.description: Any “consumer NF” can ask the NRF for information with a guessed slice identifier, until a non-error response is returned. The NRF services that are candidates for this operation are ([2]): discovery and Access token (Nnrf_NFDiscovery and Nnrf_AccessToken). For the Discovery service, in the GET NF instances, the parameters can be included “plmn-specific-snssai-list”, which contains the S-NSSAIs that are served by the NF supposedly being discovered. Then the 200OK result contains the NFProfile, which includes the S-NSSAIs.

FGT5019.004.Description: An adversary may intercept unencrypted radio transmissions of a UE's SUCI to identify the IMSI/SUPI of the UE.

Detection.description: Monitor for allowed modifications relative to the agreed upon modifications per roaming agreements and agreements with IPX.
Monitor processes which may sniff data.
Monitor commands given to NFs which may help data sniffing.

Procedure Examples.name: Non-SBI compromise
Procedure Examples.description: Adversary with access to the non-SBI interfaces (Xn, N2, N3, N4, N9) not using encryption can monitor traffic exchange and obtain UE information such as user identifiers, serving network identifiers, and location info. Non-SBI interfaces may not be encrypted for at least user plane or for control plane packets. See sections D.2.2., L.2.2., L.2.3 of [1]

Procedure Examples.name: SBI node compromise
Procedure Examples.description: The adversary with access to the SBI links, for example, with control over the 5G Service Communication Proxy (SCP) or a network infrastructure node (proxy, router, switch), may eavesdrop signaling messages if TLS encryption is not enabled. This leads to disclosure of UE authentication and authorization information, and NF IP addresses and other topology information. See [6], [7].

Procedure Examples.name: IPX node compromise
Procedure Examples.description: Adversary positioned on an IPX node can observe UE data if in the clear or easily decrypted: If a SEPP has not properly removed clear text information elements (IE) when replacing them with encrypted versions consistent with the previously negotiated protection policy or if the SEPP used a weak cipher for JWE encryption. See section G.2.4 of [1].

Procedure Examples.name: SEPP compromise
Procedure Examples.description: The adversary positioned on a SEPP, can observe information elements on the N32c interface including cipher suites used, keys, protection policies exchanged, and error messages received from the peer SEPP.  Observations on the N32f interface include cell ID and Physical Cell ID, SUPI, NF to NF signaling for a given victim UE. An adversary may utilize these observations for a number of follow-on techniques.

Mitigations.name: M1041
Mitigations.description:
Non-SBI: Use encryption (IPSec) on these interfaces. Sections 9.2, 9.3, 9.4, 9.8, 9.9 of [2], and for N26 interfaces, see 4.3.1. of [3].

SBI: Encrypt using TLS all links between NFs and between NF and SCP if one is deployed. TLS must use certificates for both client and server, and the certificate must include the SBA node type and must be checked against what the expectation is for that other party. The TLS profile should adhere to those in TS 33.210 [9]. IPSec can be optionally used to protect TLS traffic further at a lower layer. Section 13.1.0 of [2] and also [8], [9].

Roaming: For SEPP, see sections 4.2.3.3, 4.3., 4.4. of [4], and sections 13.1 and 13.2 of [2].

FGT5023.Name: Charging fraud via NF control
FGT5023.Description: An adversary controlling a control plane network function (NF) may manipulate signaling or parameters to achieve charging/billing fraud where victim is UE or operator itself.

Detection.description: Management system (OSS/BSS) checks uniqueness of charging ID for all new PDU sessions in non-roaming scenario and existing PDU sessions in handover and roaming scenario

Procedure Examples.name: SMF control
Procedure Examples.description:
An adversary may control the SMF and assign the same SMF Charging Identifier to a device data flow as that of an existing victim device, to cause charging errors. 
 (section 5.1.4 & annex A.1 of 3GPP TS 32.255).
The SMF can also pause charging for a given UE (even though not warranted), section 4.4.4. of 3GPP TS 23.502.
The SMF can also misreport 5G data used by a given UE.

Procedure Examples.name: PCF control
Procedure Examples.description: An adversary with control over the PCF can change policy so that UE is allowed to consume a service it was not subscribed to- but it will still be traceable to that UE. Section 4.3.2 of TS 23.503.

Procedure Examples.name: CHF control
Procedure Examples.description: An adversary with control over the CHF can ignore when PCF tells it that the spending limit for this subscriber has been reached, or can ignore the SMS records from the SMSF (SMSF uses POST to put in data), or the SMF itself for 5G data it reports. 3GPP TS 32.24]

Procedure Examples.name: NEF control or Application Function (AF) control exploiting weak NEF
Procedure Examples.description:
Adversary on AF can attack a weak NEF. Or, the NEF can be compromised and conduct this attack without even an AF. 
An AF can ask the NEF to change the “chargeable party” (3GPP TS 29.522 section 4.4.8, 3GPP TS 29.122 section 4.4.4). This is meant to support the AF being the chargeable party, but it’s imaginable how the AF can put a different AF as chargeable: it has to send the AF identifier, UE IP address, Sponsor ID, ASP ID, etc. even AppID

FGT5012.003.Name: Locate UE: 5G-GUTI reuse
FGT5012.003.Description: Adversary can track a device (get cell-level location) by listening for the same device ID being sent to the network.

Procedure Examples.name: Listen in for re-used 5G-GUTIs to determine UE presence in that area.
Procedure Examples.description:
Reportedly several operators do not re-allocate GUTI with every UE registration, or they do not re-allocate often enough or they use predictable pattern, as in [1], [2]. 
Exact 5G-GUTI refresh mechanism is left to implementation. Mandatory refresh of 5G-GUTI is to be done by AMF for initial registration, mobility registration update and network-initiated service request message due to paging, see section 6.12.3 of [3]
It is not necessary for the adversary to have a UE to listen, a simpler listening device suffices.

Critical Assets.name: UE location
Critical Assets.description: Location is accurate to a cell area, since the sniffer device has to be close enough to hear the UE send its 5G GUTI

FGT5008.Name: Redirection of Traffic via User Plane Network Function
FGT5008.Description: An adversary may divert user plane traffic for one or more UEs via a user-plane function, to monitor user data.

Detection.description: Monitor AF to NEF APIs for illegitimate traffic redirection requests. Monitor Nnef_TrafficInfluence_Update API calls from AF to NEF for traffic redirection requests to unauthorized DNN & S-NSSAI.

Pre-Conditions.name: Acquire UPF IP address/control
Pre-Conditions.description: An adversary must have control of the UPF IP address or a UPF

Pre-Conditions.name: Control SMF/NEF/AF
Pre-Conditions.description: An adversary must first control the SMF or NEF, or AF

Post-Conditions.name: Subscriber uplink & downlink data intercept
Post-Conditions.description: If an adversary redirects to their own server, they can access the uplink and downlink data of the subscriber, who will not be aware that the traffic is being intercepted.

Procedure Examples.name: Rogue or misconfigured SMF
Procedure Examples.description:
An adversary controlling the SMF can redirect existing uplink UE traffic by sending to UPF a N4 Session Modification Request (or: selecting another UPF- or, by sending to UPF another “Redirect server” [which the adversary controls] in the FAR in the N4 session (“The UPF reports to the SMF whether it supports traffic redirection enforcement in the UPF through the UPFunction Features IE.” [6]) Clause 5.8.2.3.3 of [5]

Similarly, the SMF can send a session modification request to the UPF and redirect UE traffic (downlink) — See clauses 4.4.1.2 & 4.4.1.3 of [4].

Procedure Examples.name: Rogue AF or rogue/misconfigured NEF
Procedure Examples.description: The “Application Function influence on traffic routing” service is designed for MEC applications for local processing of data traffic in order to reduce latency. However, this capability can be misused by rogue AF or rogue/misconfigured NEF. The traffic redirection occurs after the NEF takes action that affects the UPF behavior. Clause 5.6.7 Table 5.6.7-1 first row “Traffic Description” of [5], clause 4.3.6 of [4].

Mitigations.name: M1033
Mitigations.description: Restricted Permissions to add software to SDN Controller and Network Elements for person and non-person accounts

Mitigations.name: FGM5090
Mitigations.description: Logs from SDN Controller and network elements must be corelated to ensure unauthorize activity (file transfer, patch installs, process init) is reported.

Mitigations.name: M1047
Mitigations.description: SDN controllers and network elements scanned for file changes and processes.

FGT5016.Name: Abuse of Inter-operator Interfaces
FGT5016.Description: An adversary exploits interconnection/interworking between MNOs to obtain information about roaming user sessions or commit fraud.

Detection.description: Monitor for use of IE modification by IPX and respond when unexpected IE modifications are seen.

Pre-Conditions.name: IPX key compromise
Pre-Conditions.description: Adversary will need to compromise keys used to sign IE modifications at IPX

Pre-Conditions.name: Compromise of initiating SEPP
Pre-Conditions.description: Compromise of the initiating SEPP, typically the VPLMN SEPP, would permit an adversary to establish a protection policy that would allow IPX modification.

Procedure Examples.name: Manipulate data between two PLMNs
Procedure Examples.description: In one approach, the adversary, in a position on an IPX, could modify the messages between the vPLMN (visited PLMN) and hPLMN (home PLMN) if PRINS is used, resulting in possible information modification and/or disclosure.  Modification of an Information element (IE) could enable possible denial of service and/or information disclosure and this is addressed in [FGT5029](/techniques/FGT5029).

Procedure Examples.name: Compromise SEPP and modify signaling it sends
Procedure Examples.description: If the adversary controls a vPLMN SEPP they may modify signaling on N32 and/or generate requests to hPLMN NFs. The adversary controlled vSEPP could terminate TLS connections to hPLMN NFs and proxy requests as an adversary-in-the-middle, see [FGT1557.502](/techniques/FGT1557.502). Legitimate looking requests that could result in information disclosure or fraud may involve Value Added Service (VAS), e.g. VAS providing SEPP to the VPLMN

Critical Assets.name: SEPP
Critical Assets.description: Adversaries may need to compromise a vSEPP to perform certain activities to ensure they look legitimate.

Critical Assets.name: NFs in the vPLMN
Critical Assets.description: Adversaries may need to compromise a vPLMN NF to perform certain activities to ensure they look legitimate

Critical Assets.name: IPX signing keys
Critical Assets.description: Adversary will need to compromise keys used to sign IE modifications at IPX

Mitigations.name: M1041
Mitigations.description: Block or limit cipher choices used for JWS. Use of weak JWS ciphers could allow unauthorized disclosure

Mitigations.name: M1054
Mitigations.description: Block unauthorized IE modifications by IPX. Allow only communication where authorized IpxId is not NULL

Mitigations.name: M1056
Mitigations.description: Avoid using PRINS and use direct SEPP-SEPP with HTTP/s.  Use of the SEPP to SEPP solution instead of allowing an IPX to potentially observe and manipulate information avoids the problem. A future SEPP hub solution may also mitigate this risk by providing a more scalable SEPP to SEPP solution.

Detection.description: Response rate measurements. UDM slow response

Pre-Conditions.name: Acquire base station or UE
Pre-Conditions.description: Access to fake Base Station or fake UE to replay SUCI

Post-Conditions.name: Less or no service for legitimate UEs
Post-Conditions.description: Legitimate UEs have low or zero probability of successfully requesting access

Procedure Examples.name: SUCI replay
Procedure Examples.description:
SUCI is replayed by fake UE or gNB to the network.

UDM needs to process repeated SUCI messages from the same UE which will eventually drain resources of UDM and cause DoS attack on legitimate UE. Sections 5.2.2.1.2 & 5.2.2.2.2 of [1]

Critical Assets.name: UDM/SIDF resources
Critical Assets.description: UDM/SIDF resources are used for deconcealment of SUCI sent by legitimate UEs

References.name: 3rd Generation Partnership Project (3GPP) TR 33.846: “Study on Authentication Enhancements in the 5G System”, Technical Report, v17.0.0, Dec. 2021.

Mitigations.name: FGM5499
Mitigations.description: Rate limiting at NFs. SEAF or AUSF (NFs upstream from SIDF) can do rate limiting if they receive the same SUCI multiple times within a short period.

FGT5015.Name: Device Database Manipulation
FGT5015.Description: An adversary may compromise the Equipment Identity Register (EIR) function and add new equipment, modifies status (ok vs. stolen or prohibited) of mobile device.

Detection.description: Difficult to detect unauthorized changes. Inspect logs of what changes were made and by whom in the EIR

Procedure Examples.name: EIR database compromise
Procedure Examples.description:
Reference [1], DC-003, calls for the MNOs to employ an EIR. The rest of the attack is theoretical: an adversary may modify some of the entries in the EIR database, e.g. device status (stolen, etc.)
The AMF is the only function that checks the EIR based on permanent equipment id (PEI), upon UE registration (using the API N5g-eir_EquipmentIdentityCheck_Get).

Critical Assets.name: Integrity of device database
Critical Assets.description: Device databases should be kept from tampering.

Critical Assets.name: User equipment status integrity
Critical Assets.description: UE status should be kept accurate.

References.name: GSM Association, “GSM Association Official Document FS.31, Baseline Security Controls.”, v2.0, Feb. 2020

Mitigations.name: FGM5020
Mitigations.description: Secure EIR function

FGT1199.501.Name: MNO Roaming Partners
FGT1199.501.Description: An adversary may breach or otherwise leverage a mobile network operator's (MNO's) roaming partners or their service partners to gain access to subscriber's services or obtain information about that subscriber from their home network.

Detection.description: Analysis of application logs on the HPLMN SEPP and PLMN NFs  may indicate unusual control channel activity.
Analysis of network traffic from VAS, and/or IPX may indicate unexpected or unusual traffic.

Pre-Conditions.name: Compromised partner
Pre-Conditions.description: An adversary must already have compromised a trusted VPLMN or one of their service providers, e.g. IPX, VAS, etc.

Pre-Conditions.name: Compromised credentials
Pre-Conditions.description: An adversary may need compromised legitimate credentials that could be used to obtain information from the MNO

Pre-Conditions.name: Identified vulnerability
Pre-Conditions.description: An adversary may need to identify a vulnerability in an MNO network function to send specially crafted requests to obtain initial access.

Procedure Examples.name: Partner supply chain compromise
Procedure Examples.description: The service partner of the MNO targeted may themselves be targeted as part of an attack chain using that roaming partners supply chain

Procedure Examples.name: Partner insider
Procedure Examples.description: A roaming partner, may have an adversary with a privileged position in the roaming or service partners organization and can use that position to attempt additional techniques against the targeted MNO.

Critical Assets.name: SEPP
Critical Assets.description: An adversary would want to compromise the cSEPP as it is the VPLMN end-point for the N32c channel to the HPLMN

Critical Assets.name: VPLMN UPF
Critical Assets.description: An adversary would want to compromise the VPLMN UPF as it is used as an endpoint on the roaming network for the N9 user plane interface between UPFs

Critical Assets.name: VAS
Critical Assets.description: An adversary would want to compromise a trusted VAS with access to the MNO’s core functions

References.name: 5GS Roaming Guidelines Version 5.0 (non-confidential), NG.113-v5.0, GSMA, December 2021
5G; Security Architecture and Procedures for 5G System, TS 33.501 v16.10.0 Release 16, Sections 9.9, 13.1, 13.2, 3GPP, March 2022

R. Pell, S. Moschoyiannis, E. Panaousis, R. Heartfield, “Towards dynamic threat modelling in 5G core networks based on MITRE ATT&CK”,  October 2021

Mitigations.name: M1030
Mitigations.description: Minimize exposure of functions to only those partner functions that need to access.

Mitigations.name: M1018
Mitigations.description: Management of credentials used by partners to be scoped to the least privilege can minimize potential abuse.  Does not mitigate misuse within allowed privileges.

Mitigations.name: M1037
Mitigations.description: Ensure communication with functions such as a SEPP is constrained to necessary addresses, ports, and protocols.

Mitigations.name: M1054
Mitigations.description: Validation of credentials properly can mitigate some MITM attacks and ensure revoked/expired credentials are not allowed.

FGT5004.002.Name: Network Flow Manipulation: vSwitch
FGT5004.002.Description: An adversary may compromise a vSwitch in an SDN network to manipulate the network traffic  or cause denial of service

Detection.description: Analyze logs to detect unauthorized activity
Periodically audit SDN and Network element configuration and compare with baseline configuration to detect unauthorized changes
Periodically audit network flow tables to detect unauthorized changes to flow data

Pre-Conditions.name: Credential and Access to SDN vSwitch
Pre-Conditions.description: Privileged Access to SDN vSwitch via direct login or through SDN control plane APIs

Post-Conditions.name: Network flow compromise
Post-Conditions.description: Network flow compromise can lead to DOS, or change the traffic pattern and paths.  Adversary may change the path for network sniffing or for MiTM activity.

Critical Assets.name: SDN vSwitch, operations, and security tools
Critical Assets.description: Adversary may target a particular network controller, network element, CI/CD, security, and operations tools to manipulate SDN network flows in a vSwitch

Critical Assets.name: SDN vSwitch Configuration file
Critical Assets.description: Adversary may target configuration to manipulate vSwitch and network behavior

Critical Assets.name: SDN vSwitch flow table
Critical Assets.description: Network flows are stored in Network Flow tables, usually refer to as route or switch tables that vSwitch uses to decide which packet forwarding port to use for incoming packets

Mitigations.name: FGM5091
Mitigations.description: Mutual authentication between SDN controller and vSwitch can prevent unauthorized access

Mitigations.name: FGM1557
Mitigations.description: Strong integrity protection method should be employed on APIs carrying control plane traffic between Controller and network element as well as controller and vSwitch to avoid adversary in the middle threats

Mitigations.name: M1041
Mitigations.description: Strong encryption should be used on APIs carrying control plane traffic between Controller and network element as well as controller and vSwitch to avoid adversary in the middle threats

Mitigations.name: FGM5090
Mitigations.description: Logs from SDN Controller and network elements must be corelated to ensure unauthorize activity is reported. Similarly flow rules change log should be reviewed and reconciled with authorized changes.

Mitigations.name: M1053
Mitigations.description: SDN vSwitch configurations should be backed up and periodically audited to see differences between running configuration and back up configurations

Mitigations.name: M1054
Mitigations.description: Keep baseline configuration up to date to avoid loopholes due to stale configuration or configuration drift.

Mitigations.name: M1030
Mitigations.description: Physical and logical segmentation can prevent lateral movements. Segmentation techniques in the hosts and network will reduce the chances of lateral movement to the control.

FGT5001.Name: Network-side SMS collection
FGT5001.Description: An adversary may compromise the operator's SMS Center (SMSC) to collect SMS messages to/from the UEs.

Pre-Conditions.name: Malware developed
Pre-Conditions.description: Adversary must first develop the malware to achieve the procedures herein.

Procedure Examples.name: Malware loaded into a Linux running SMSC server
Procedure Examples.description: A data miner program may be loaded by an installation script. The script targets and saves SMS messages (the contents, the IMSI and the source and destination phone number). This is highly targeted to given IMSI numbers (e.g., proponents of movements against the Chinese gov’t). (note: Call Data Records (CDRs) were also targeted for certain IMSIs, the info therein is called metadata, i.e. time, duration, phone numbers). [1], [2].

Critical Assets.name: User data
Critical Assets.description: User data from SMS

References.name: Dynamic Ciso.com “New Malware Discovered by FireEye APT41, Infects SMS Servers Within Telecoms”, Nov 1, 2019, retrieved March 4, 2022.
Leong, Raymond, Perez, Dan & Dean, Tyler, “MESSAGETAP: Who’s Reading Your Text Messages” FireEye. 31 Oct 2019.

Mitigations.name: M1049
Mitigations.description: Check telecom servers for malware or use endpoint security solution. Implement the latest patches in Linux systems and use strong anti-virus software to detect malware.

Detection.description: Monitor process creation and OS API execution activity.
Monitor for the deployment of suspicious or unknown container images and pods in your environment, particularly containers running as root.
Monitor cluster-level (Kubernetes) data and events associated with changing containers' volume configurations.

Procedure Examples.description: Container was configured to bind to the host root directory

Procedure Examples.name: S0601
Procedure Examples.description: Hildegard used the BOtB tool that can break out of Container

Procedure Examples.name: S0683
Procedure Examples.description: Peirates can gain a reverse shell on a host node by mounting the Kubernetes hostPath.

Procedure Examples.name: S0623
Procedure Examples.description: Siliscape maps the hosts’s C drive to the contianer by creating a global symbolic link of NtSetInformationSymbolicLink

Procedure Examples.name: G0139
Procedure Examples.description: TeamTNT has deployed privileged containers that mount the filesystem of victim machine

Critical Assets.name: Credentials

Mitigations.name: M1048
Mitigations.description: Consider utilizing seccomp, seccomp-bpf, or a similar solution that restricts certain system calls such as mount. In Kubernetes environments, consider defining a Pod Security Policy that limits container access to host process namespaces, the host network, and the host file system

Mitigations.name: M1038
Mitigations.description: Use read-only containers, read-only file systems, and minimal images when possible, to prevent the running of commands.

Mitigations.name: M1026
Mitigations.description: Rootless containers: Ensure containers are not running as root by default. In Kubernetes environments, consider defining a Pod Security Policy that prevents pods from running privileged containers.

Inadequate / defective security devices.

Unprotected Data Centre Interconnection channels areas.

Improper physical secure perimeter or isolation between tenants.

Pre-Conditions.name: MEC host
Pre-Conditions.description:

Improper security monitoring of edge computing facilities

Insecure service environment.

Mitigations.name: FGM5005
Mitigations.description:
Communications Centers.
Communication centers should provide a full set of physical and environmental controls aimed to assure access control, monitoring, continuity of operations and protection against environmental disasters.

FGT5018.003.Name: Vandalism of Network Infrastructure: Edge servers
FGT5018.003.Description: An adversary may seek physical access to isolated/remote edge servers using covert methods of entry with the intent to damage or destroy edge computing facilities, gaining unauthorized access at system level as an entry point to all hosted resources, theft of data on local storage, vandalism, and sabotage.

Detection.description: Event logs recording user activities, exceptions, faults and information security events should be produced, kept and regularly reviewed. Additional considerations: development of use-case specific alert rules, integration and correlation of data at all levels (network, application), integration and correlation with service provider-level monitoring mechanisms.

Pre-Conditions.name: Improper security monitoring of edge computing facilities
Pre-Conditions.description: Mobile-edge computing have to be integrated in the network-wide Security Incident and Monitoring System, but with additional considerations: development of use-case specific alert rules, integration and correlation of data at all levels (network, application), integration and correlation with service provider -level monitoring mechanisms. Failure to do so may leave advanced or sustained threats undetected, as well as technical failures or malfunctions of local resources.

Post-Conditions.name: Service unavailability
Post-Conditions.description: Destruction of assets, unauthorized access, theft of data on local storage, vandalism, sabotage

Post-Conditions.name: Information destruction
Post-Conditions.description: Destruction or damage of these assets may cause information destruction

Procedure Examples.name: Damage edge servers
Procedure Examples.description: Adversary may obtain physical access to remote edge servers and cause damage to them.

Critical Assets.name: Edge facility equipment
Critical Assets.description: Destruction of edge computing facilities, unauthorized access at system level as an entry point to all hosted resources, theft of data on local storage, vandalism and/or sabotage of equipment.

References.name: European Union Agency for Cybersecurity (ENISA): “ENISA Threat Landscape for 5G Networks” Report, page 202, December 2020.

Mitigations.name: FGM5005
Mitigations.description: Edge sites should be provided with a full set of physical and environmental controls aimed to assure access control, monitoring, continuity of operations and protection against environmental disasters. FGT5045.Name: Telecom Protocol Payload
FGT5045.Description: Adversaries may hide their data within a legitimate telecom protocol payload in order to evade defenses such as firewall measures

FGT5040.Name: Discover operator private key
FGT5040.Description: Adversary sends many arbitrary but cryptographically weak SUCI values in registration requests in order to discover private key of MNO using information received from failure/success responses.

FGT5038.Name: Network Slice application resource hijacking
FGT5038.Description: An adversary may use compromised container management SW (or account) in MANO domain to gain access to target VNFs and its resources for unauthorized access to resources/data of another slice in NFVI or resource exhaustion of target application resulting in denial of service.

FGT1557.502.Name: Roaming and Interconnection
FGT1557.502.Description: An adversary may act as an adversary-in-the-middle (AITM) between two mobile network operators to enable activities like network sniffing (FGT1040) or transmitted data manipulation (FGT1565.002).

Detection.description: Monitor for access to SEPP application/appliance for unexpected access.
Analyze network traffic to/from SEPP to determine if from unexpected source/dest and consistent with expected traffic from other operators.

Mitigations.name: M1030

FGT5036.Description: Adversary may use AI/ML training data and prediction poisoning techniques to manipulate the outcomes of a machine learning model for malicious purposes, to disrupt service or change the behavior of network elements.

FGT5041.Description: Adversary sends fake SBI message to NRF to de-register a legitimate NF from 5G network.

FGT1498.504.Description: Adversary  may change the main clock source of PTP in a legitimate gNB to achieve Denial of Service on RAN.

FGT5025.Description: An adversary in a roaming partner operator may send altered service usage for a given UE to the home operator of that UE.

Cross-check with subscriber services (if subscriber complains)

Procedure Examples.description: Signaling fraud may be undertaken by a partner operator, via false charging over international signaling interconnection. In [1] section 5.3. Reference [2] mentions service fraud.
